_source.Study Protocol Description: The APH Science Carrier is a root module that is divided into four quadrants, each independently controlled. Each quadrant is filled with a porous granular ceramic substrate that was sieved to a particle size of 1-2 mm. The substrate was washed with DI water to remove dust and autoclaved in a covered tray for 30 minutes. The substrate was dried in a forced air oven at 70 degrees C for a minimum of 72 hours until thoroughly dry. Dry and sterile 1-2 mm substrate was weighed and mixed with Nutricote controlled release fertilizer prills. Each quadrant of the Science Carrier was filled with 990 grams of substrate and planted with 12 pepper seeds placed in 3 rows and secured with guar. The overall planting density was 240 plants per meter squared. Seeds were planted in April 2021 and the science carrier was sealed inside a bag and was packaged in foam before being launched from the Kennedy Space Center on Space X CRS-22 on 3 June 2021. The pre-planted science carrier was installed in the APH facility by the Flight Engineer on 12 July 2021 and imbibed until saturated. A team at KSC continuously monitored and tele-operated the experiment from Earth, controlling watering, lighting, and other environmental conditions. The plants germinated and grew for 14 days at an average photosynthetic photon flux of 300 micromol per meter squared per second, a photoperiod of 15 hours day / 8 hours night and an average air temperature setting of 23 degrees C, 80% Relative Humidity, and a wind speed of 0.3 m/s were selected set points and changed as the study progressed. There were 3 pre-programmed light settings throughout the study each having an average of 300 micromol per meter squared per second at three different heights from the science carrier surface. As the plant grew to each of these heights, the lighting was adjusted accordingly. The light spectral quality was 27% red, 33% green, and 40% blue light. The CO2 concentration was controlled at 550 ppm throughout the experiment to reduce the effects of intumescence however CO2 concentrations varied as the plants matured. After 14 days the relative humidity was reduced to 50% and the root zone volumetric moisture content was lowered to 50% respectively. The root zone volumetric moisture was lowered again to 40-45% after thinning to one plant per quadrant and maintained until the end of the experiment. Ethylene concentration was controlled by recirculating the APH chamber air through a scrubber filled potassium permanganate coated pellets. Wind speed was increased periodically after flowers were first seen to assist in flower pollination. Hand pollination was also conducted on each flower by a crew member. During the growth period, the crew thinned the plants on day 28, removed debris from the chamber on days 40, 50, 70, 90, and 110, inserted plant support stands on day 50 to stabilize and provide support to the plant stems, assisted with hand pollination, and harvested the plants.     Harvests took place on day 137. At the completion of the second harvest in November 2021, the PH-04 SC was stowed at ambient temperature and returned to Earth in January 2022. Fruit and leaves were wrapped and stored at -80 degrees C on the ISS until returned to Earth and maintained at that temperature until processing. The Science carrier was returned to KSC where it was placed at 4 degrees C until processing. Samples were taken from the science carrier / root tray surface using swabs and components were sampled. Fruit and leaves were frozen at -80 degrees C in the station's MELFI and maintained at that temperature when received at KSC until processing.     All samples were processed for molecular sequencing. Microbial DNA was isolated from approximately 100 mg of plant tissue (leaf, stem, root, fruit, and seed) or component and placed in a 2 mL sterile screw cap centrifuge tube with up to 4 sterile, stainless steel beads (2.8mm) and flash frozen in liquid nitrogen. Samples were immediately processed in a Bead Ruptor Cryo Mill for 2 minutes at a frequency of 30 Hz. After processing through the Cryo Mill and minimizing tissue thaw, 300 micro liters of power bead solution from the DNeasy UltraClean Microbial Kit was added to the 2 mL tube and vortexed to mix the contents. The subsequent extraction followed the manufacturer's recommendations. Liquid samples from water and swabs were collected after microbial sampling was completed and centrifuged to collect the cell component. Pellets were recovered and the DNA was isolated using the DNeasy UltraClean Microbial kit. DNA was quantified using the Qubit ds DNA Assay for downstream application. The foam and wick samples processed in the same way as the swab samples.     16S PCR was completed with V4 region, customized barcoaded 15S rRNA gene primers as described by Kosich et al. 2013. The PCR master mix contained 1x PCR buffer, 2.25 mM MgCL2, 300 mM dNTPs, 300 nM forward and reverse primers, and 0.25 units of Platinum Taq polymerase. Each reaction was completed in duplicate with 1ng of DNA template per reaction. The thermocycling conditions were denatured at 95 degrees C for e5 minutes followed by 30 cycles at 95 degrees C for 10 minutes completed the PCR. Replicates of PCR reaction were combined, and cleaned with Min-Elute Cleanup System to remove excess primers and dNTPs. Amplicon concentration was determined with the Qbit 2.0 ds DNA assay and nanomolar concentration calculated for each sample. Samples were diluted to 4nM and an equimolar concentration library was created per Illumina's library preparation guidelines.     The library was spiked with a 10% PhiX aliquot to the library and sequenced on the Illumina MiSeq platform with a 500 cycle V2 sequencing kit with 250 bp paired ends and FASTQ reads at more than 30 quality score.     Fastq format was checked with fastq_utils v0.25.1. Quality assessment of reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.12.
_source.Study Description: Growing plants in spaceflight presents challenges to achieve optimal plant growth and productivity. One of NASA's goals is growing edible crops in spaceflight to supplement the astronauts' diet with fresh vegetables and assess food safety of the crops. It is important to understand the optimal growing conditions for crops grown in spaceflight conditions. Leafy greens have been grown on the International Space Station in the Veggie plant chamber and were safe for the astronauts to eat. The Advanced Plant Habitat (APH), an enclosed, controlled plant growth facility on the ISS has also been used to grow edible plants. The technology demonstration in the APH grew chile peppers, Capsicum annum c.v. NuMex Espanola Improved. This was one of the longest continuous plant growth experiments conducted on ISS (137 days), producing 26 pepper fruit.

_source.Study Protocol Description: Astronauts were instructed to swab a 5cm x 5cm surface on selected racks and locations across nine USOS modules, avoiding connector panels, utility panels, cables, and non-permanent stow bags (with the exception of modules primarily used for stowage, where surfaces available for sampling mostly comprised stow bags). A raster pattern with a zigzag technique was suggested for surface sampling.     Total nucleic acid extraction was performed from one cotton swab of each dual headed sampling device  (n equals 803) using the MagMAX Microbiome Ultra total nucleic acid isolation kit (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat A42357), as previously described. Briefly, 96-well extraction bead-plates pre-filled with surface swabs or control aliquots in each well (see Sample collection and plating) were subjected to total nucleic acid extraction following the manufacturer’s protocol. Lysis was performed with a TissueLyser II (Qiagen). Bead clean-ups were performed with the KingFisher flex purification system (Thermo Fisher Scientific).     We performed low-biomass, 16S V4 rRNA gene (16S) amplicon sequencing on nucleic acid extractions (n equals 803) using KatharoSeq methods and Earth Microbiome Project (EMP) PCR primers. KatharoSeq incorporates appropriate controls during sample processing to disambiguate true biological signal in low-biomass samples from background noise that arises from reagent kit and plasticware contaminants. Amplicon library preparation was performed through miniaturized PCR reactions as previously described. Due to the low-biomass characteristics of dry surface swabs, a higher template nucleic acid input volume was used, compared to the standard EMP 16S protocol (https://earthmicrobiome.org/protocols-and-standards/16s/). Briefly, for a miniaturized 10µL total PCR reaction volume, 3.6 µL of PCR-grade water, 4.0µL of Platinum Hot Start PCR Master Mix (2x)(Thermo Fisher, Cat 13000014), 0.2µL of Forward primer (10 µM), 0.2µL of Reverse primer (10 µM), and 2µL of extracted total nucleic acid were mixed into each well of a 384-well PCR plate. PCR amplification followed the standard EMP thermocycler conditions. 16S amplicon libraries were equal volume pooled and PCR cleaned using the QIAquick PCR Purification Kit (Qiagen, Cat 28104).     Clean library pools were sequenced on the Illumina MiSeq platform using MiSeq 300 cycle (2x151 paired end reads) reagent kit (v2) (Illumina, Cat MS-102-2002) and custom sequencing primers outlined in the standard EMP 16S protocol.     Fastq format was checked with fastq_utils v0.25.1. Quality assessment of reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.12.     Pure solvent used as instrumental blanks. Mixed standard solution of six chemicals as instrument internal standards. Swabs extracted with 50:50 ethanol:water (v:v).     Data-dependent acquisition using a Vanquish ultra-high performance liquid chromatography (UHPLC) system coupled to a Q Exactive quadrupole orbitrap mass spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA). Chromatography column was Kinetex C18 column (50 × 2.1 mm, 1.7 µm particle size, 100 A pore size; Phenomenex, Cat 00B-4475-AN) with SecurityGuard C18 column (2.1 mm ID; Cat AJ0-8782) at 30 °C column temperature. The mobile phases (0.5 mL/min) were 0.1 % formic acid (Fisher Scientific Cat A117-50) in both water (A) and ACN (B) with the following gradient: 0-1 min 5 % B, 1-7 min 5-100 % B, 7-7.5 min 100 % B, 7.5-8 min 100-5% B, 8-10 min 5% B.     The raw spectra were converted to .mzML files using MSconvert (ProteoWizard).     Shotgun sequencing libraries from samples that passed KatharoSeq thresholds were prepared following a high-throughput, miniaturized KAPA HyperPlus (Roche, Cat KK8514) library preparation protocol, exhaustively described previously. Briefly, DNA from each sample was quantified using the Quant-iT PicoGreen dsDNA assay kit (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat KK8514), and then normalized to 5 ng in 3.5µL of molecular-grade water using an Echo 550 acoustic liquid-handling instrument (Labcyte). When sample DNA concentration was insufficient to reach the intended 5 ng input, a 3.5µL aliquot of sample was transferred. During library preparation with KAPA HyperPlus, reagents for each step (enzymatic fragmentation, end-repair and A-tailing, and adaptor ligation) were added at a 1:10 ratio of the recommended volumes, using a Mosquito HV micropipetting robot (SPT Labtech). Fragmentation was performed at 37ºC for 20 min. Sequencing adapters and barcode indices were added in two steps, following the iTru strategy previously described. First, the Mosquito HV robot was used to add universal ‘stub’ adapters and ligase mix to the end-repaired DNA, and the ligation reaction was incubated for 30 min at 20ºC. Adapter-ligated DNA was purified using AMPure XP (Beckman Coulter, Cat A63881) magnetic beads and a BlueWasher purification robot (BlueCat Bio) at a ~0.8X bead:sample ratio, with one 80% ethanol wash. Clean beads were resuspended in 6µL of molecular-grade water. Later, the elution was transferred into a PCR plate with unique i5 and i7 index combinations (iTru). The PCR plate was produced by aliquoting 5µL of KAPA HiFi PCR MasterMix (Roche,Cat  KK2602) to a 384-well PCR plate, and dispensing 0.25µL of each unique primer pair (0.25µL of i5 and 0.25µL of i7) to each well. Secondly, the purified adapter-ligated DNA was amplified by transferring 4.5µL of elution of each sample to the 5.5µL of PCR master mix per well, in a 384-well PCR plate. The 10µL PCR reaction was amplified for 15 cycles following the recommended KAPA HyperPlus thermal cycling conditions. Amplified shotgun library was purified with AMPure XP magnetic beads and the BlueWasher (BlueCatBio), as described earlier, at a ~0.8X bead:sample ratio. Each sample was eluted into 10µL of water, and the elution was transferred to a 384-well echo compatible plate (Labcyte, Cat NC1731983) using a Mosquito HV. Samples were equal volume pooled using the Echo 550 liquid handler (Labcyte). The sequencing pool was quality checked with an TapeStation (Agilent, Cat  5067-5584 and Cat  5067-5585), size selected to a 300 - 700 bp range using a Pippin Prep electrophoresis instrument (Sage Sciences, Cat HTC2010).     The sequencing pool was sequenced on a low-output iSeq v2 (300 cycle) (Illumina, Cat 20031371) sequencing platform to generate sequence count distributions.  A second, normalized sample pool was generated from sequence count normalization, as previously described139. The normalized pool was quality checked, size selected, and sequenced (2x151 paired end reads) on a lane of a NovaSeq 6000 S4 flowcell v1.5 (300 cycle) (Illumina, Cat  20028312).     Utilizing kraken2 v2.1.1, a human genome reference database was constructed from NCBI's RefSeq (GCF_000001405.39) GRCh38.p13, with --no-masking, and defaults of kmer-length 35 and minimizer-length of 31. FASTQ files were screened against this database, and all successfully classified reads were removed.     Fastq format was checked with fastq_utils v0.25.1. Quality assessment of reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.12.
_source.Study Description: Space habitation provides unique challenges in built environments isolated from Earth. We produced a 3D map of the microbes and metabolites throughout the International Space Station (ISS), with 803 samples collected during space flight, including controls. We find that the use of each of the nine sampled modules within the ISS strongly drives the microbiology and chemistry of the habitat. Relating the microbiology to other Earth habitats, we find that, as with human microbiomes, built environment microbiomes also align naturally along an axis of industrialization, with the ISS providing an extreme example of an industrialized environment. We demonstrate the utility of culture-independent sequencing for microbial risk monitoring, especially as the location of sequencing moves to space. The resulting resource of chemistry and microbiology in the space-built environment will guide long-term efforts to maintain human health in space for longer durations.

_source.Study Protocol Description: In the Rodent Research Reference Mission (RRRM-1), forty female BALB/cAnNTac mice were flown on the International Space Station. To assess differences in outcomes due to age, twenty 10-12 week-old and twenty 32 week-old mice were flown, respectively. To directly assess spaceflight effects, half of the young and old mice (10 old, 10 young) were sacrificed on-orbit after 22-23 days (ISS Terminal, ISS-T), while the other half (10 old, 10 young) were returned live to Earth after 40 days and allowed to recover for 2 days (Live Animal Return, LAR) before sacrifice. Both the ISS-T and LAR animals had independent ground controls (10 mice housed in flight hardware in matched environmental conditions), basal controls (10 mice sacrificed 1 day after launch), and vivarium controls (10 mice housed within standard vivarium habitats). Thus RRRM-1 included a total of 160 mice. All mice (BALB/cAnNTac) were sourced from Taconic Biosciences (Germantown, NY). Mice were weighed, chipped with BMDS RFID chip (IMI-500) and shipped to NASA KSC for delivery at approximately L-4 weeks. Mice were housed and maintained in the Animal Care Facility (ACF) at NASA KSC with 12:12 light cycle matched in timing to the light cycle used for Transporters and Habitats programmed for flight. All mice were housed in cages of 5 mice/cage with the same littermates as they had been raised. Mice were initially given ad lib standard lab chow and water, which was changed on a schedule of 2x per week. Mice were housed initially on standard bedding and provided igloo-type enrichment. Animal health was checked daily by appropriately trained NASA personnel and contracted lab technicians. At L-3 weeks, mice were placed on raised mesh flooring to simulate spaceflight Transporter and Habitat cage conditions, given water delivered through lixits identical to those used in the flight hardware and put on the NASA Nutrient-Upgraded Rodent Foodbars (NuRFB). Food and water was changed weekly and mice were weighed bi-weekly. Igloo-type enrichment was provided in all cages. At L-10 days, mice were grouped (10 mice per cage) in larger cages for social acclimation prior to launch. Groupings were done based on age of animals and with regard to establishing similar average weights between any given grouping. At L-2 days, baseline, spaceflight and ground control groups were identified. At L-1 day, spaceflight animals were loaded into spaceflight Transporters. Habitat Ground Control (HGC) mice were loaded into Transporters on a 3-day offset from spaceflight animals. Vivarium Ground Control (VGC) mice (also on a 3-day offset) were returned to 5 mice/cage and placed on standard bedding and provided water through typical sipper tubes at launch equivalent. All mice were maintained on NuRFB throughout the duration of the study. Spaceflight and HGC mice were given new food at weekly intervals. VGC mice were given new food and fresh water also on weekly intervals. Mold contamination of food: Spaceflight and Habitat Ground Control mice were exposed to mold in their food to unknown relative degrees. The Vivarium Control and Baseline Control mice had clean food throughout their habitation. Loose food bars: Food bars came loose and fell to the bottom of the cage for the HGC mice and was free floating for the Spaceflight mice. This did not prevent the mice from eating. This may have caused some degree of stress for these animals that would have been experienced differently between the Spaceflight and HGC groups. Live animal return: Because weather in the Pacific was very poor, mice experienced double density housing (10 per cage instead of 5) for at least 7 days instead of the expected 2-3 days. Habitat Ground Control mice were treated the same way but this duration of double-density housing probably created additional stress on both groups of mice. In addition, because of rough seas, the Spaceflight mice might have experienced some sea sickness-type conditions that would not have been experienced by the HGC mice. The study followed recommendations in the Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals and the protocol was approved by the NASA Flight Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC). GeneLab only processed 68 and 77 samples from LAR and ISS-T groups, respectively, in this dataset for a total of 145 processed samples.     Live Animal Return (LAR) samples: Mice were anesthetized with gas anesthesia and euthanized by means of cardiac puncture blood draw (exsanguination) and double thoracotomy. Fecal samples and other tissues were removed and preserved using liquid nitrogen after euthanasia. All groups (baseline, flight, habitat and vivarium ground controls) were treated identically. All samples were maintained at -80C or lower temperatures throughout the storage during transportation and shipment. ISS Terminal (ISS-T) samples: Mice were anesthetized with ketamine/xylazine and euthanized by means of cardiac puncture blood draw (exsanguination) and double thoracotomy. The carcass was then wrapped in foil and frozen in MELFI on board the ISS or in ground -80C freezers. Carcasses were maintained at -80C or lower temperatures throughout the storage on board the ISS, in ground freezers and during transportation and shipment. For fecal sample collection, carcasses were thawed at room temperature one at a time (staggered) until the tissues were sufficiently pliable for dissection (approximately 60-90 minutes). Once thawed, tissues were removed from each carcass and preserved using liquid nitrogen. All samples were maintained at -80C or lower temperatures throughout the storage in ground freezers and during transportation and shipment.     DNA was extracted using the Maxwell RSC Purefood GMO and Authentication Kit (Promega, Madison, WI) following GeneLab SOP 3.3 Feces DNA Extraction using Maxwell RSC instrument with PureFood GMO kit. 0.5-2 fecal pellet(s) (based on amount in tube and mass of pellet range 10-15 mg) was/were placed into a tube with 1 mL CTAB solution and homogenized using tissue homogenizing bead mix (Navy RINO Lysis, Next Advance, Raymertown, NY) on Bullet Blender Gold 24 (Next Advance, Raymertown, NY) for 3 minutes at 4 ˚C following GeneLab SOP 2.1 Tissue homogenization using Bullet Blender Bead Beater. Homogenates were centrifuged for 5 minutes at 4 ˚C and 21,000 g to deflate foam. The supernatant from each sample was then used to isolate and purify DNA following the manufacturer's protocol. DNA was eluted in 60-140 µL RNAse free H2O (60-120 used for LAR sample extraction in 2023 because of low DNA yield, higher DNA yield in 2024 resulted in use of 130-140 uL H2O) and was further cleaned using OneStep PCR Inhibitor Removal Kit (Zymo Research, Irvine, CA). Concentrations for all DNA samples were measured using Qubit 3.0 Fluorometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA) with Qubit DNA HS kit following SOP 4.1-RNA/DNA/miRNA/cDNA Quantification using Qubit Fluorimeter. DNA quality and size were assessed using the Agilent 4200 TapeStation with Agilent gDNA ScreenTape Kit (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA) following GeneLab SOP 4.2 QC Genomic DNA. GeneLab Sample Processing SOP can be found at the GitHub page, https://github.com/nasa/GeneLab-sampleProcessing/tree/master/SOP_docs.     DNA library was prepared with the Illumina DNA Library Prep kit (Illumina, San Diego, CA) by GeneLab Sample Processing Lab. Input DNA were approximately 100-500 ng. All libraries (Preps 2-5) were prepared entirely on the epMotion, except for Prep 1, for which the epMotion had an error and the library cleanup step was done manually. Index adapters were IDT for Illumina, 96-well DNA Dual Index Adapters, set C, and Nextera DNA UD Indexes, Plate C. 5 cycles PCR were performed. Library fragment size was assessed using Agilent 4200 TapeStation with D1000 DNA ScreenTape (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA) following GeneLab SOP 6.3 Quality analysis of sequencing libraries using 4200 TapeStation System with D1000 reagent kit. For all prep batches except for Prep 1, the average library fragment sizes were assessed as being too large (~700 to greater than 900 bp), and several manual cleanups (0.4-0.6x bead:sample ratios on a few samples were tested, 0.55x ratio used for most samples) were performed to correct library size to a sequencable range (average of 641 bp). Pooled library concentration was measured by Qubit 4 Fluorometer (ThermoFisher Scientific, Waltham, MA) following GeneLab SOP 4.1-RNA/DNA/miRNA/cDNA Quantification using Qubit Fluorimeter. Library quality assessment was performed on iSeq100 (Illumina, San Diego, CA). Libraries were pooled and balanced based on read count. GeneLab Sample Processing SOP can be found at the GitHub page, https://github.com/nasa/GeneLab-sampleProcessing/tree/master/SOP_docs.     DNA sequencing was performed by GeneLab Sample Processing Lab on Illumina NovaSeq 6000. Sequencing was set up as following: Read 1: 251 bp, Index1: 10 bp, Index2: 10 bp Read 2: 251 bp. PhiX included as control and to increase library diversity. Protocol followed is SOP 7.1-Setting up NovaSeq 6000 and iSeq 100 Sequencers. GeneLab Sample Processing SOP can be found at the GitHub page, https://github.com/nasa/GeneLab-sampleProcessing/tree/master/SOP_docs.     Human reads were identified and removed from the raw data as described in GL-DPPD-7105-A (https://github.com/nasa/GeneLab_Data_Processing/blob/master/Metagenomics/Remove_human_reads_from_raw_data/Pipeline_GL-DPPD-7105_Versions/GL-DPPD-7105-A.md). In short, human reads were identified and removed from the raw data using kraken2 (v2.1.1) against a human genome reference database that was constructed from NCBI's RefSeq (GCF_000001405.39) GRCh38.p13. The database was constructed by running kraken build with the following parameters: --no-masking, kmer-length 35, and minimizer-length 31.     Non-human reads were assessed for the percent mouse reads as described in GL-DPPD-7109 (https://github.com/nasa/GeneLab_Data_Processing/blob/master/Metagenomics/Estimate_host_reads_in_raw_data/Pipeline_GL-DPPD-7109_Versions/GL-DPPD-7109.md). In short, mouse reads were classified and quantitated from the non-human reads using kraken2 (v2.1.1) against a mouse genome reference database that was constructed from NCBI's RefSeq (GCF_000001635.27) GRCm39. The database was constructed by running kraken build with the following parameters: --no-masking, kmer-length 35, and minimizer-length 31.     Human reads removed fastq file quality was evaluated with FastQC (version 0.12.1), and MultiQC (version 1.17) was used to generate MultiQC reports.
_source.Study Description: In Rodent Research Reference Mission-1 (RRRM-1), forty female BALB/cAnNTac mice were flown on the International Space Station. To assess differences in outcomes due to age, twenty 10-12 week-old and twenty 32 week-old mice were flown, respectively. To directly assess spaceflight effects, half of the young and old mice (10 old, 10 young) were sacrificed on-orbit after 22-23 days (ISS Terminal, ISS-T), while the other half (10 old, 10 young) were returned live to Earth after 40 days and allowed to recover for 2 days (Live Animal Return, LAR) before sacrifice. Both the ISS-T and LAR animals had independent ground controls (10 mice housed in flight hardware in matched environmental conditions), basal controls (10 mice sacrificed 1 day after launch), and vivarium controls (10 mice housed within standard vivarium habitats). Thus RRRM-1 included a total of 160 mice. Feces were removed from 145 animals and preserved by flash freezing in liquid nitrogen and stored at -80 ˚C until DNA was extracted, and libraries generated and sequenced (target 10 M clusters per sample, PE 251 bp). This dataset features whole-genome shotgun metagenomics sequencing data from 8-10 feces samples per group.

_source.Study Protocol Description: All Veggie pillows were assembled at Kennedy Space Center, FL and prepared for flight as described in detail by Massa et al., 2017. Crop seeds were sanitized using a bleach/ hydrochloric acid (HCl) fuming method. Approximately 75–100 seeds were batch sanitized by adding 0.5 ml concentrated HCl to 30 ml bleach (5% sodium hypochlorite solution) in a 500 ml wide-mouth jar and placing an open petri dish containing the seeds into the bleach container, without submersion, then sealing the container to maintain the chlorine fumes around the seeds. Seeds were sanitized for 1 h before being removed from the acid/bleach container for off-gassing overnight (approximately 24 h) in a laminar flow hood. Two seeds were planted in Veggie pillows in calcined clay (arcillite)  and 7.5 g/ liter− 1 of 18–6-8, type 100-day time-release fertilizer (Nutricote Florikan ESA, Sarasota, FL, United States). Seeds were germinated and grown in controlled-environment growth chambers simulating environmental conditions aboard the ISS (50% relative humidity, 3000-ppm CO2, temperature 23 C). The photoperiod was set at 16 h/8 h light dark cycles with LED lights providing 200–300 μmol m− 2 s− 1 photosynthetically active radiation (PAR). During VEG-03D operation, a fan anomaly occurred, causing a rise in humidity to 100% for approximately 25 days inside the Veggie facility and condensation on the bellows surface.     Pillows were thinned to a single plant per pillow . Four harvests were completed.  Samples from harvest 2 and 4 were frozen and returned for analysis. Plant tissues were separated into leaf and root and placed in pre-weighed 50-ml tubes containing sterile water and glass beads and analyzed for microbial load using culture based and molecular methods. Surface swab samples were collected by the crew from 8 different sites within or on the Veggie facility using self-contained sterile swabs (Becton Dickinson, Franklin Lakes, NJ, USA), three from the interior bellows, one from the upper one-third of the bellows, one in the middle, and the third from the lower portion, three plant pillow top surfaces, one from the internal fan screen, and one from the fan outlet vent ports. After sample collection, the swabs were returned to the sterile container and stored frozen at -80 C in the Minus Eighty Laboratory Freezer on ISS (MELFI).     DNA was isolated from each sample using the Qiagen Cell Kit and was followed by PCR  for the 16S rRNA gene for bacteria and barcoded primers for the internal transcribed spacer (ITS) for fungi.     Samples were diluted to 4 nM and an equimolar concentration library was created per Illumina’s library preparation guidelines. The library was spiked with a 10% PhiX aliquot to add diversity to the library.     Sequencing was completed using the Illumina MicroSeq V2500 cycle  kits. Sequencing was completed as paired end on the Illumina MiSeq Next Generation Sequencer (NGS). FastQ sequences were identified to the genus level using the RDP/GreenGenes and SILVA (bacteria) and Unite (fungal) databases.     Fastq format was checked with fastq_utils v0.25.1. Quality assessment of reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.12.

_source.Study Publication Title: Spatial Characterization of Microbial Communities on Multi-Species Leafy Greens Grown Simultaneously in the Vegetable Production Systems on the International Space Station
_source.Study Description: Investigates the microbial communities of plants and Veggie pillow components with culturable and non-culturable methods providing qualitative and quantitative data. This studies also stresses the food safety component of fresh crops grown on the ISS. The VEG-03D technology demonstration was completed achieving simultaneous multi-species plant growth within a Veggie unit on the International Space Station (ISS). Microbiological characterization using molecular and culture-based methods was performed on leaves and roots from two harvests of three leafy greens, red romaine lettuce (Lactuca sativa cv. ‘Outredgeous’); mizuna mustard, (Brassica rapa var japonica); and green leaf lettuce, (Lactuca sativa cv. Waldmann’s) and associated rooting pillow components and Veggie chamber surfaces. Culture based enumeration and pathogen screening indicated the leafy greens were safe for consumption. Surface samples of the Veggie facility and plant pillows revealed low counts of bacteria and fungi and are commonly isolated on ISS. Community analysis was completed with 16S rRNA amplicon sequencing. Comparisons between pillow components, and plant tissue types from VEG-03D, E, and F revealed higher diversity in roots and rooting substrate than the leaves and wick. This work provides valuable information for food production-related research on the ISS and the impact of the plant microbiome on this unique closed environment.

_source.Study Protocol Description: DNA was isolated from each sample using the Qiagen Cell Kit and was followed by PCR for the 16S rRNA gene for bacteria and barcoded primers for the internal transcribed spacer (ITS) for fungi.     Samples were diluted to 4 nM and an equimolar concentration library was created per Illumina’s library preparation guidelines. The library was spiked with a 10% PhiX aliquot to add diversity to the library.     Sequencing was completed using the Illumina MicroSeq V2500 cycle kits. Sequencing was completed as paired end on the Illumina MiSeq Next Generation Sequencer (NGS) with 250-bp paired ends and FASTQ reads at greater than 30 quality score.     Fastq format was checked with fastq_utils v0.25.1. Quality assessment of reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.12.     All Veggie pillows were assembled at Kennedy Space Center, FL and prepared for flight as described in detail by Massa et al., 2017. Crop seeds were sanitized using a bleach/ hydrochloric acid (HCl) fuming method. Approximately 75–100 seeds were batch sanitized by adding 0.5 ml concentrated HCl to 30 ml bleach (5% sodium hypochlorite solution) in a 500 ml wide-mouth jar and placing an open petri dish containing the seeds into the bleach container, without submersion, then sealing the container to maintain the chlorine fumes around the seeds. Seeds were sanitized for 1 h before being removed from the acid/bleach container for off-gassing overnight (approximately 24 h) in a laminar flow hood. Two seeds were planted in Veggie pillows in calcined clay (arcillite) and 7.5 g/ liter− 1 of 18–6-8, type 100-day time-release fertilizer (Nutricote Florikan ESA, Sarasota, FL, United States). Seeds were germinated and grown in controlled environmental conditions aboard the ISS (50% relative humidity, 3000-ppm CO2, temperature 23 C). The photoperiod was set at 16 h/8 h light dark cycles with LED lights providing 200–300 μmol m− 2 s− 1 photosynthetically active radiation (PAR).     Pillows were thinned to a single plant , grown for 28 days and 3 additional harvests were completed.  Plants were harvested as multiple harvests with samples collected and placed in the -80 ° C until returned to Earth. Samples were maintained at -80 until processing. Plants were separated into leaf and root tissue, and 3 samples of media, and wick were collected. All harvests were completed using aseptic techniques to minimize contamination. Plant tissues were separated into leaf and root and placed in pre-weighed 50-ml tubes containing sterile water and glass beads.

_source.Study Title: SpaceX Inspiration4 Oral, Nasal, and Skin Metagenomic and Metatranscriptomic Microbial Swabs
_source.Study Funding Agency: Funding provided by NASA, NIH, and philanthropic donations. NNX14AH50G, NNX17AB26G, 80NSSC22K0254, NNH18ZTT001N-FG2, NNX16AO69A
_source.Study Protocol Description: DNA, RNA and proteins were isolated from each sample using the QIAGEN AllPrep DNA/RNA/Protein Kit (QIAGEN, cat  47054) according to the manufacturer’s protocol, yet omitting steps one and two. In order to lyse biological material from each sample, 350uL of each sample was transferred to a QIAGEN PowerBead Tubes with 0.1mm glass beads and secured to a Vortex-Genie 2 using an adapter (cat 1300-V1-24) before being homogenized for 10 minutes. 350uL of the subsequent lysate was then transferred to a spin-column before proceeding with the protocol. Concentration of the isolated DNA, RNA and protein for each sample were measured by fluorometric quantitation using the Qubit 4 Fluorometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, cat  Q33238) and a corresponding assay kit.  The Qubit 1Xds DNA HS Assay Kit for DNA concentration (cat  Q33231), the RNA HS Assay Kit (cat  Q32855) for RNA concentration.     Illumina DNA Library prep kit was used for preparing all extracted DNA samples for Illumina Whole genome sequencing per manufacturer’s instructions. Adapters used were IDT® for Illumina® DNA/RNA UD Indexes, Tagmentation (96 Indexes, 96 Samples).     All libraries were pooled and sequenced on a S4 flow cell of the Illumina NovaSeq 6000 Sequencing System with 2 × 150 bp paired-end reads.     Utilizing kraken2 v2.1.1, a human genome reference database was constructed from NCBI's RefSeq (GCF_000001405.39) GRCh38.p13, with --no-masking, and defaults of kmer-length 35 and minimizer-length of 31. FASTQ files were screened against this database, and all successfully classified reads were removed.     Fastq format was checked with fastq_utils v0.25.1. Quality assessment of reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.12.     Quality assessment of reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.11. Quality-trimming and filtering was performed with bbmap v38.86. Read-based processing was performed with humann v3.6. Individual samples were assembled with megahit v1.2.9. Genes were called with prodigal v2.6.3. Taxonomic classification of genes and contigs was performed with CAT v5.2.2. Functional annotation was done with KOFamScan v1.3.0. Reads were mapped to assemblies with bowtie2 v2.3.5.1, and coverage information was extracted for reads and contigs with samtools v1.9 and bbmap v38.86. Binning of contigs was performed with metabat2 v2.15. Bins were summarized with bit v1.8.53 and estimates of quality were generated with checkm v1.1.3. High-quality bins (greater than 90% est. completeness and less than 10% est. redundancy) were taxonomically classified with gtdb-tk v1.5.0.     For library preparation, total RNA samples were sent to Hudson Alpha. Samples were treated with DNAse 1 (Zymo Research, Catalog   E1010). Post-DNAse digested samples were then put into the NEBNext rRNA depletion v2 (Human/Mouse/Rat), Ultra II Directional RNA (10 ng), and Unique Dual Index Primer Pairs were used following the vendor protocols from New England Biolabs. Completed libraries were quantified by Qubit or equivalent and run on a Bioanalyzer or equivalent for size determination. Libraries were pooled and quantified by Qubit fluorometer (ThermoFisher Scientific), TapeStation 2200 (Agilent), and qRT-PCR using the Kapa Biosystems Illumina library quantification kit.     All libraries were pooled and sequenced on a S4 flow cell of the Illumina NovaSeq 6000 Sequencing System with 2 × 150 bp paired-end reads.     Raw fastq file quality was evaluated with FastQC (version 0.12.1), and MultiQC (version 1.17) was used to generate the raw MultiQC report.     All subjects were consented at an informed consent briefing (ICB) at SpaceX (Hawthorne, CA), and samples were collected and processed under the approval of the Institutional Review Board (IRB) at Weill Cornell Medicine, under Protocol 21-05023569. All crew members have consented for data and sample sharing. We sequenced analyzed samples from human skin, oral, and nasal, environmental swabs before, during, and after a 3-day mission to space.     Body swabs were collected from ten different sites, comprising three microbial ecosystems (oral, nasal, skin) around the body at eight different timepoints surrounding launch. These are referred to as L-92, L-44, L-3, FD1, FD2, R+1, R+45, R+82, where “L-” refers to pre-launch, “FD” corresponds to flight day (i.e., mid-flight), “R” refers to recovery (i.e., post-flight). Open air control, swab water control, laboratory control are also collected. The crew were each provided sterile Isohelix Buccal Mini Swabs (Isohelix, cat MS-03) and 1.0mL dual-barcoded screw-top tubes (Thermo Scientific, cat 3741-WP1D-BR/1.0mL) prefilled with 400uL of DNA/RNA Shield storage preservative (Zymo Research, cat  R1100). Isohelix swabs were dipped in nuclease-free water (on-Earth) or Hfactor hydrogen infused water (in-flight). Eight skin swab sites: post-auricular, axillary vault, volar forearm, occiput, umbilicus, gluteal crease, glabella, and the toe-web space. Following sample collection, swabs were immediately transferred to the barcoded screw-top tubes and kept at room temperature for less than 4 days before being stored at 4C until processing.

_source.Study Publication Title: Longitudinal multi-omics analysis of host microbiome architecture and immune responses during short-term spaceflight     The Space Omics and Medical Atlas (SOMA) and international astronaut biobank     Collection of Biospecimens from the Inspiration4 Mission Establishes the Standards for the Space Omics and Medical Atlas (SOMA)
_source.Study Description: The SpaceX Inspiration4 mission was a 3-day mission with four private astronauts to low Earth orbit that occurred in September 2021. The crew collected biospecimen samples before, during, and after flight. One of these biospecimen collections included oral, nasal, and skin microbial swabs collected from ten locations (oral, nasal cavity, post-auricular, axillary vault, volar forearm, occiput, umbilicus, gluteal crease, glabella, and toe web space). Skin swabs were first dipped in nuclease-free water before swabbing each region for 30 seconds. Oral and nasal swabs did not include this swab-wetting step. Nuclease-free water samples were sequenced as controls. Swabs were collected at three pre-flight timespoints (L-92, L-44, L-3), two in-flight timepoints (flight day 2 (FD2), and flight day 3 (FD3)), and three post-flight timepoints (R+1, R+45, R+82). Swabs were stored in 400uL of Zymo Research DNA/RNA Shield at 4C until nucleic acid extraction. DNA and RNA were extracted from the same swab to generate metagenomic and metatranscriptomic profiles.

_source.Study Title: Predicting how varying moisture conditions impact the microbiome of dust collected from the International Space Station (ISS)
_source.Study Funding Agency: NASA Space Biology Grant #80NSSC19K0429
_source.Study Protocol Description:
DNA was extracted from 25 mg dust samples before and after incubations using a DNeasy Powerlyzer Power Soil Kit (Qiagen, Hilden, Germany) with a modified bead mixture (1 g garnet, 0.3 g 100 µm glass beads, and 0.1 g 500 µm beads). Each DNA extraction run included a blank and confirmed to contain no microbial DNA. A total of 50 µL of DNA extract was collected for each sample and stored at -20℃ until use.     Amplicon library preparation used the standard two-step approach recommended by Illumina for generating libraries and was performed by RTL Genomics (Lubbock, TX, USA). Fungal primers: ITS1F (CTTGGTCATTTAGAGGAAGTAA) and ITS2aR (GCTGCGTTCTTCATCGATGC). ribosomal DNA primers - Bacterial primers: 515F (5’-GTGCCAGCMGCCGCGGTA) and 806R (5’-GGACTACHVHHHTWTCTAAT).     All sequencing was performed on an Illumina MiSeq (TM) using a read length of 2 x 300 base pairs.     - Quantitative Insights Into Microbial Ecology 2 (QIIME2), version 2021.8, was used to analyze raw FASTQ sequencing data For fungal sequences: - Primers and spacers were trimmed using the Cutadapt plug-in - Paired-ends joined using the VSEARCH join-pairs method - Sequences were trimmed to a Phred score of 30 with a 3 low-quality base window using the Quality-filter plugin - Sequences were clustered using the vsearch open reference method with Unite database reference sequences (version 9.0) - The Basic Local Alignment Search Tool (BLAST) version 2.9.0, User-friendly Nordic Internal Transcribed spacer Ectomycorrhiza (UNITE) 2019 database, and Fungal High-throughput Taxonomic tool for use with Next-Generation Sequencing (FHitINGS) version 1.4 were used to identify fungal taxonomy For bacterial sequences: - Sequences were run through the Dada2 pipeline - Sequences were clustered by phylogeny - Bacterial taxa was classified in QIIME2 using the feature-classifier plugin which utilized the Greengenes database version 13_8     Fastq format was checked with fastq_utils v0.25.1. Quality assessment of reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.12.     ISS Dust Samples: All dust used in this study was obtained from vacuum bags (CELOC hypoallergenic filter system Oreck  PKBB12DW) from the vacuum onboard the ISS which astronauts use to clean the HEPA filter coverings that are part of the air ventilation system. It is important to note that we had no control of when, how much, or where these vacuums were used while onboard, which means other areas may have also been vacuumed in addition to the HEPA filter coverings. In total, ISS dust from 4 separate vacuum bags were returned to Earth and analyzed in this study. ISS vacuum bags 1-4 were collected by the ISS crew on GMT 264 (September 21, 2018), GMT 102 (April 12, 2019), GMT 243 (August 31, 2019), and GMT 286 (October 13, 2019) and returned to Earth on SpaceX16 (January 13, 2019), SpaceX-17 (July 3, 2019), and SpaceX-19 (January 7, 2020). In total, it took approximately 6, 5, 6, and 4 months for bags 1, 2, 3, and 4 to reach our lab at OSU from the actual collection date onboard ISS. For ISS vacuum bag 1, the full vacuum bag was sent directly to The Ohio State University Indoor Environmental Quality Laboratory. ISS vacuum bags 2-4 were first sent to the Toxicology and Environmental Chemistry group at NASA’s Johnson Space Center (Houston, TX, USA) and then a subsample of dust was sent to us for analyses. In addition, we received dust samples which were frozen onboard the ISS, returned in cold stowage, and sent directly to our laboratory, where they were stored at -80°C until use.

Incubations: All incubation were completed in a sterilized 3.8 L glass chamber and placed in a VWR incubator (Model TFFU20F2QWA Radnor, PA USA) set to 25°C. Sodium chloride (NaCl) and Magnesium Chloride (MgCl2) solutions were used to simulate 50%, 60%, 70%, 80%, 85%, and 90% ERH conditions. Deionized (DI) water alone was used to create 100% ERH conditions. Salt solutions were measured for water activity (aw) using an Aqualab™ Dew Point Water Activity Meter (Decagon 125 Devices Pullman, WA USA) and adjusted as needed. All incubation chambers contained approximately 50 mL of salt solution or DI for the desired ERH condition and an Onset® HOBO® Data logger (Onset Computer Corporation, Bourne, MA USA) to monitor Equilibrium Relative Humidity (ERH) and temperature. Dust samples were not sieved and measure out into approximately 25 mg portions that were placed on sterile aluminum foil on a plastic dish. Two-week incubations consisted of triplicate samples for each ISS bag and ERH condition (3 samples from each bag per incubation chamber) similar to previous studies. Time-of-wetness incubations followed a procedure previously outlined. Time-of-wetness refers to the time fraction per day that relative humidity conditions are above the 80% threshold. This framework was applied to microbial growth in ISS dust by calculating the relative growth rates at days 5, 10, 14, and 21 at elevated (85% ERH) and saturated (100% ERH) conditions which cycled between 50% ERH for 6, 12, 18, and 24 hours during separate incubations. To obtain the relative growth rate (R/k), we first calculated the growth rates (k) for constant (24 hours/day) elevated and saturated conditions. Next, the effective growth rates (R) were calculated for each condition (elevated and saturated) at 6-, 12-, and 18-hour time points. The relative growth rate was calculated for each bag at each time-of-wetness first, then these values were averaged to obtain the averaged maximum relative growth rate for each time point and ERH condition. Samples were extracted and quantified at days 5, 10, 14, and 21 after incubation (One 25 mg dust sample per day per bag). All incubation chambers were covered with parafilm to retain ERH conditions and allow CO2 to escape.
_source.Study Publication Author List: Nastasi N  Haines SR  Bope A  Meyer ME  Horack JM  Dannemiller KC.
_source.Study Publication Title: Fungal diversity differences in the indoor dust microbiome from built environments on earth and in space.
_source.Study Description: On Earth, people spend 90% of their time indoors where dust and moisture can facilitate rapid microbial growth, especially fungi. The International Space Station is a specialized closed environment that contains own unique indoor microbiome. Elevated moisture such as from a temporary ventilation system malfunction may lead to unintended microbial growth indoors, which is associated with negative health outcomes and degradation of essential built environment materials. We need to develop a predictive approach for modeling microbial growth to understand when it may occur in these critical indoor spaces. Here we demonstrate that exposure to even fluctuating elevated relative humidity above 80% can lead to rapid microbial growth and community composition changes in dust from spacecraft. We were able to model fungal growth in space station dust using the time-of-wetness framework with activation and deactivation limited growth occurring at 85% and 100% relative humidity conditions, respectively. Alpha and beta diversity of fungi was altered with both significantly decreasing as relative humidity and time elevated increased. Our results demonstrate that we can use moisture conditions to develop predictive models for fungal growth and composition. Understanding microbial growth in spacecraft can protect astronaut health, spacecraft integrity, and promote planetary protection as human activity increases in low-Earth orbit, the moon, Mars, and beyond.

_source.Study Protocol Description: DNA, RNA and proteins were isolated from each sample using the QIAGEN AllPrep DNA/RNA/Protein Kit (QIAGEN, cat 47054) according to the manufacturer’s protocol, yet omitting steps one and two. In order to lyse biological material from each sample, 350uL of each sample was transferred to a QIAGEN PowerBead Tubes with 0.1mm glass beads and secured to a Vortex-Genie 2 using an adapter (cat 1300-V1-24) before being homogenized for 10 minutes. 350uL of the subsequent lysate was then transferred to a spin-column before proceeding with the protocol. Concentration of the isolated DNA, RNA and protein for each sample were measured by fluorometric quantitation using the Qubit 4 Fluorometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, cat Q33238) and a corresponding assay kit. The Qubit 1Xds DNA HS Assay Kit for DNA concentration (cat Q33231), the RNA HS Assay Kit (cat Q32855) for RNA concentration.     For library preparation, total RNA samples were sent to Hudson Alpha. Samples were treated with DNAse 1 (Zymo Research, Catalog E1010). Post-DNAse digested samples were then put into the NEBNext rRNA depletion v2 (Human/Mouse/Rat), Ultra II Directional RNA (10 ng), and Unique Dual Index Primer Pairs were used following the vendor protocols from New England Biolabs. Completed libraries were quantified by Qubit or equivalent and run on a Bioanalyzer or equivalent for size determination. Libraries were pooled and quantified by Qubit fluorometer (ThermoFisher Scientific), TapeStation 2200 (Agilent), and qRT-PCR using the Kapa Biosystems Illumina library quantification kit.     All libraries were pooled and sequenced on a S4 flow cell of the Illumina NovaSeq 6000 Sequencing System with 2 × 150 bp paired-end reads.     Utilizing kraken2 v2.1.1, a human genome reference database was constructed from NCBI's RefSeq (GCF_000001405.39) GRCh38.p13, with --no-masking, and defaults of kmer-length 35 and minimizer-length of 31. FASTQ files were screened against this database, and all successfully classified reads were removed.     Fastq format was checked with fastq_utils v0.25.1. Quality assessment of reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.12.     All subjects were consented at an informed consent briefing (ICB) at SpaceX (Hawthorne, CA), and samples were collected and processed under the approval of the Institutional Review Board (IRB) at Weill Cornell Medicine, under Protocol 21-05023569. All crew members have consented for data and sample sharing. We sequenced analyzed samples from human skin, oral, nasal and environmental swabs before, during, and after a 3-day mission to space.     The crew collected biospecimen samples before, during, and after flight. One of these biospecimen collections included microbial swabs collected from nine surfaces in the Dragon capsule (execute button, G-meter button, control touch screen - left, control touch screen - right, side hatch mobility aid, lid of waste locker, seat 2, commode panel, viewing dome) and one open air control. Swabs were collected twice during flight (flight day 2 (FD2), and flight day 3 (FD3)) and twice pre-flight in the crew training capsule in Hawthorne, CA (L-92, L-44). Isohelix swabs were dipped in nuclease-free water (on-Earth) or Hfactor hydrogen infused water (in-flight). Areas of the SpaceX Dragon Capsule were swabbed for 30 seconds using both sides of the swab. Swabs were then stored in 400uL of Zymo Research DNA/RNA Shield (cat  1100) and kept at room temperature for less than 4 days before being stored at 4C until processing.     Illumina DNA Library prep kit was used for preparing all extracted DNA samples for Illumina Whole genome sequencing per manufacturer’s instructions. Adapters used were IDT® for Illumina® DNA/RNA UD Indexes, Tagmentation (96 Indexes, 96 Samples).     All libraries were pooled and sequenced on a S4 flow cell of the Illumina NovaSeq 6000 Sequencing System with 2 × 150 bp paired-end reads.     Fastq format was checked with fastq_utils v0.25.1. Quality assessment of reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.12.     Quality assessment of reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.11. Quality-trimming and filtering was performed with bbmap v38.86. Read-based processing was performed with humann v3.6. Individual samples were assembled with megahit v1.2.9. Genes were called with prodigal v2.6.3. Taxonomic classification of genes and contigs was performed with CAT v5.2.2. Functional annotation was done with KOFamScan v1.3.0. Reads were mapped to assemblies with bowtie2 v2.3.5.1, and coverage information was extracted for reads and contigs with samtools v1.9 and bbmap v38.86. Binning of contigs was performed with metabat2 v2.15. Bins were summarized with bit v1.8.53 and estimates of quality were generated with checkm v1.1.3. High-quality bins (greater than 90% est. completeness and less than 10% est. redundancy) were taxonomically classified with gtdb-tk v1.5.0.

_source.Study Description: The SpaceX Inspiration4 mission was a 3-day mission with four private astronauts to low Earth orbit that occurred in September 2021. The crew collected biospecimen samples before, during, and after flight. One of these biospecimen collections included microbial swabs collected from nine surfaces in the Dragon capsule (execute button, G-meter button, control touch screen - left, control touch screen - right, side hatch mobility aid, lid of waste locker, seat 2, commode panel, viewing dome) and one open air control. Swabs were collected twice during flight (flight day 2 (FD2), and flight day 3 (FD3)) and twice pre-flight in the crew training capsule in Hawthorne, CA (L-92, L-44). Swabs were stored in 400uL of Zymo Research DNA/RNA Shield at 4C until nucleic acid extraction. DNA and RNA were extracted from the same swab to generate metagenomic and metatranscriptomic profiles.

_source.Study Protocol Description: All subjects were consented at an informed consent briefing (ICB) at SpaceX (Hawthorne, CA), and samples were collected and processed under the approval of the Institutional Review Board (IRB) at Weill Cornell Medicine, under Protocol 21-05023569. All crew members have consented for data and sample sharing. We sequenced analyzed samples from human skin, oral, nasal and environmental swabs before, during, and after a 3-day mission to space.     For fecal collection, all subjects are provided with DNA Genotek OMNIgene-GUT (OM-200) kits for gut microbiome DNA collection. Each subject was instructed to empty their bladder and collect a fecal sample free of urine and toilet water. From the fecal specimen, each subject used a sterile single-use spatula, provided by the OMNIgene-GUT kit, to collect the feces and deposit it into the OMIgene-GUT tube. Once deposited and sealed, the user was instructed to shake the sealed tube for 30 seconds in order to homogenize the sample and release the storage buffer. All samples from each timepoint were stored at room temperature for less than 3 days before storing at -80°C long-term. Fecal samples collected using the OMNIgene-GUT kit are stable at room temperature (15°C to 25°C) for up to 60 days.     DNA was isolated from each sample using the QIAGEN PowerFecal ProRO DNA Kit (cat  51804). OMNIgene-GUT tubes thawed on ice (4°C) and vortexed for 10 seconds before transferring 400uL of homogenized feces into the QIAGEN PowerBead Pro Tube with 0.1mm glass beads and secured to a Vortex-Genie 2 using an adapter (cat  1300-V1-24) before being homogenized at maximum speed for 10 minutes. The remainder of the protocol was completed as instructed by the manufacturer. The concentration of the isolated DNA was measured by fluorometric quantitation using the Qubit 4 Fluorometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, cat  Q33238), and the Qubit 1Xds DNA Broad Range Assay Kit was used for DNA concentration (cat  Q33265).     For shotgun metagenomic sequencing, library preparation for Illumina NGS platforms was performed using the Illumina DNA FLEX Library prep kit (cat  20018705) with IDT for Illumina DNA/RNA US Indexes (cat  20060059).     Following library preparation, quality control was assessed using a BioAnalyzer 2100 (Agilent, cat  G2939BA) and the High Sensitivity DNA assay. All libraries were pooled and sequenced on the Illumina NextSeq 2000 Sequencing System with 2 × 150 bp paired-end reads.     Utilizing kraken2 v2.1.1, a human genome reference database was constructed from NCBI's RefSeq (GCF_000001405.39) GRCh38.p13, with --no-masking, and defaults of kmer-length 35 and minimizer-length of 31. FASTQ files were screened against this database, and all successfully classified reads were removed.     Fastq format was checked with fastq_utils v0.25.1. Quality assessment of reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.12.     Quality assessment of reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.11. Quality-trimming and filtering was performed with bbmap v38.86. Read-based processing was performed with humann v3.6. Individual samples were assembled with megahit v1.2.9. Genes were called with prodigal v2.6.3. Taxonomic classification of genes and contigs was performed with CAT v5.2.2. Functional annotation was done with KOFamScan v1.3.0. Reads were mapped to assemblies with bowtie2 v2.3.5.1, and coverage information was extracted for reads and contigs with samtools v1.9 and bbmap v38.86. Binning of contigs was performed with metabat2 v2.15. Bins were summarized with bit v1.8.53 and estimates of quality were generated with checkm v1.1.3. High-quality bins (higher than 90% est. completeness and lower than 10% est. redundancy) were taxonomically classified with gtdb-tk v1.5.0.

_source.Study Protocol Description: Collected skin was flash embedded in OCT blocks. Three or 4 replicate OCT-embedded tissues were placed on a single slide per patient including pre and post flight replicates.     Immunofluorescent visualization marker for Pan-Cytokeratin (PanCK, Novus cat  NBP2-33200,  Alexa Fluor® 532, clone ID AE1 + AE3), fibroblast activation protein (FAP, Abcam cat  ab222924, Alexa Fluor® 594, clone ID EPR20021) and smooth muscle actin (SMA, R and D Systems cat  IC1420R, Alexa Fluor® 647, clone 1A4) were used for region or interest (ROI) selection. The DSP whole transcriptome assay (WTA) was used to assess genes collected in each ROI. For DSP processing, OCT slides were thawed overnight in 10% NBF at 4°C followed by PBS washes for thorough fixation.  After washes, slides were prepared following the automated Leica Bond RNA Slide Preparation Protocol for fixed frozen samples, digesting samples with 1.0 µg/mL protease K for 15 min, and antigen retrieval for 20 min at 100°C (NanoString, no. MAN-10115-05). In situ hybridizations with the GeoMx Whole Transcriptome Atlas Panel (WTA, v1.0, 18,677 genes) at 4 nM final concentration were done in Buffer R (NanoString). Morphology markers were prepared for four slides concurrently using Syto13 (DNA), PanCK, FAP and SMA in Buffer W for a total volume of 225 μl per slide. Slides incubated with 225 μl of morphology marker solution at RT for 1 h, then washed in SSC and loaded onto the NanoString DSP instrument. The No Template Control was used to detect contamination in the library prep.     Libraries were constructed with Illumina adapters for paired end sequencing.     Libraries were sequenced using the Illumina NovaSeq 6000 sequencer.     Images were captured using the NanoString GeoMx system. The 20x scan was used to select freeform ROIs to guide selection of outer epidermal (OE), inner epidermal (IE), outer dermal (OD) and vascular (VA) regions.     FASTQ files were converted to digital count conversion files using the NanoString GeoMx NGS DnD Pipeline (v2.3.4). From the normalized count matrix, DESeq2 (v1.34.0) was used to perform differential expression analysis.     Fastq format was checked with fastq_utils v0.25.1. Quality assessment of reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.12. rRNA percentages of reads were estimated with the 'hts_SeqScreener' program of htstream v1.3.3 screened against a fasta file of H-sapiens rRNA sequences retrieved from NCBI on 01-Sep-2021.     DNA and RNA were extracted with the Qiagen Allprep Bacterial DNA/RNA/Protein Kit (cat  47054).     For library preparation, total RNA samples were sent to Hudson Alpha. Samples were treated with DNAse 1 (Zymo Research, Catalog   E1010). Post-DNAse digested samples were then put into the NEBNext rRNA depletion v2 (Human/Mouse/Rat), Ultra II Directional RNA (10 ng), and Unique Dual Index Primer Pairs were used following the vendor protocols from New England Biolabs. Completed libraries were quantified by Qubit or equivalent and run on a Bioanalyzer or equivalent for size determination. Libraries were pooled and quantified by Qubit fluorometer (ThermoFisher Scientific), TapeStation 2200 (Agilent), and qRT-PCR using the Kapa Biosystems Illumina library quantification kit.     Libraries were sequenced using 2 x 150 Paired end sequencing on an S4 flow cell using the Illumina NovaSeq 6000 sequencer.     Utilizing kraken2 v2.1.1, a human genome reference database was constructed from NCBI's RefSeq (GCF_000001405.39) GRCh38.p13, with --no-masking, and defaults of kmer-length 35 and minimizer-length of 31. FASTQ files were screened against this database, and all successfully classified reads were removed.     Fastq format was checked with fastq_utils v0.25.1. Quality assessment of reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.12.     Illumina DNA Library prep kit was used for preparing all extracted DNA samples for Illumina Whole genome sequencing per manufacturer’s instructions. Adapters used were IDT® for Illumina® DNA/RNA UD Indexes, Tagmentation (96 Indexes, 96 Samples).     Libraries were sequenced using 2 x 150 Paired end sequencing on an S4 flow cell using the Illumina NovaSeq 6000 sequencer.     Fastq format was checked with fastq_utils v0.25.1. Quality assessment of reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.12.     Quality assessment of reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.11. Quality-trimming and filtering was performed with bbmap v38.86. Read-based processing was performed with humann v3.6. Individual samples were assembled with megahit v1.2.9. Genes were called with prodigal v2.6.3. Taxonomic classification of genes and contigs was performed with CAT v5.2.2. Functional annotation was done with KOFamScan v1.3.0. Reads were mapped to assemblies with bowtie2 v2.3.5.1, and coverage information was extracted for reads and contigs with samtools v1.9 and bbmap v38.86. Binning of contigs was performed with metabat2 v2.15. Bins were summarized with bit v1.8.53 and estimates of quality were generated with checkm v1.1.3. High-quality bins (greater than 90% est. completeness and less than 10% est. redundancy) were taxonomically classified with gtdb-tk v1.5.0.     All subjects were consented at an informed consent briefing (ICB) at SpaceX (Hawthorne, CA), and samples were collected and processed under the approval of the Institutional Review Board (IRB) at Weill Cornell Medicine, under Protocol 21-05023569. All crew members have consented for data and sample sharing.     Skin biopsies were performed on the deltoid region of the arm from the L-44 and R+1 timepoint. Each site was prepared by application of ChloraPrep and anesthesia was induced with administration of 1% lidocaine with 1:100,000 epinephrine. A trephine punch was used to remove a 3- or 4-mm diameter piece of skin. The resected piece was cut into approximately ⅓ and ⅔ sections. The larger piece was placed in a cryovial and stored at -80°C for spatial transcriptomics. One-third of the sample was stored in formalin and kept at room temperature to perform histology. Skin swabs: Isohelix swabs were dipped in nuclease-free water. Swabs were then stored in 400uL of Zymo Research DNA/RNA Shield (cat 1100).

_source.Study Publication Title: The Space Omics and Medical Atlas (SOMA) and international astronaut biobank     Collection of biospecimens from the inspiration4 mission establishes the standards for the space omics and medical atlas (SOMA)     Spatial multi-omics of human skin reveals KRAS and inflammatory responses to spaceflight
_source.Study Description: The SpaceX Inspiration4 mission was a 3-day mission with four private astronauts to low Earth orbit that occurred in September 2021. The crew collected biospecimen samples before, during, and after flight. One of these biospecimen collections included deltoid skin biopsies, collected once pre-flight (L-44) and within 1 day postflight (R+1). Biopsies were 3mm - 4mm in diameter and were frozen at -80C at the time of collection. Samples were then embedded in OCT and prepared for spatially resolved transcriptomics using the NanoString GeoMx Whole Transcriptome Atlas Panel. Skin was profiled in four regions: outer epidermis (OE), inner epidermis (IE), outer dermis (OD), and vasculature (VA) regions. Four crew members were profiled pre-fight (C001, C002, C003, C004) and three crew members were profiled post-flight (C002, C003,  C004). Additionally, skin swabs of the deltoid region were collected before each biopsy. Skin swabs were first dipped in nuclease-free water before swabbing each region for 30 seconds. Swabs were stored in 400uL of Zymo Research DNA/RNA Shield at 4C until nucleic acid extraction. DNA and RNA were extracted from the same swab to generate metagenomic and metatranscriptomic profiles.
