_source.Study Protocol Description: One fecal pellet (equivalent in mass) was used per mouse for DNA extraction and bacterial DNA was isolated using the QIAGEN Power Fecal DNA isolation kit (QIAGEN, Cat. No. 12955-4) with bead beating. Total DNA isolated for 16S ribosomal RNA gene sequencing was also utilized for metagenomic sequencing. Oral samples collected via Plasdent Maxaplicator Super fine (2 mm) swabs were used for collection (MPN 600-R-2). Oral Swab DNA samples were processed using the Lucigen - Master Pure DNA isolation kit (Ca. No. MC85200).     Whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing was performed at the University of Washington's Northwest Genomics Center (NWGC) on 10 biological replicates for both ISS and ISS_G rodents respectively (N equals 20). Sequencing libraries were generated using KAPA HTP Library Preparation Kits (07961901001, Roche) and sequenced on an Illumina NovaSeq 6000 System using a S Prime flow cell configured for 300 cycles which resulted in a total of 1,342,813,654 reads with an average of 70,674,403 reads per sample. Raw paired-end reads were then filtered, trimmed for quality, and screened against a mouse (C57BL) reference database using kneadData (McIver et al., 2018).     Utilizing kraken2 v2.1.1, a human genome reference database was constructed from NCBI's RefSeq (GCF_000001405.39) GRCh38.p13, with --no-masking, and defaults of kmer-length 35 and minimizer-length of 31. FASTQ files were screened against this database, and all successfully classified reads were removed.     Utilizing kraken2 v2.1.1, a mouse genome reference database was constructed from NCBI's RefSeq (GCF_000001635.27) GRCm39, with --no-masking, and defaults of kmer-length 35 and minimizer-length of 31. FASTQ files were screened against this database, and all successfully classified reads were counted and reported as a percentage of the total.     Quality assessment of reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.11. Quality-trimming and filtering was performed with bbmap v38.86. Read-based processing was performed with humann v3.6. Individual samples were assembled with megahit v1.2.9. Genes were called with prodigal v2.6.3. Taxonomic classification of genes and contigs was performed with CAT v5.2.2. Functional annotation was done with KOFamScan v1.3.0. Reads were mapped to assemblies with bowtie2 v2.3.5.1, and coverage information was extracted for reads and contigs with samtools v1.9 and bbmap v38.86. Binning of contigs was performed with metabat2 v2.15. Bins were summarized with bit v1.8.53 and estimates of quality were generated with checkm v1.1.3. High-quality bins (greater than 90% est. completeness and less than 10% est. redundancy) were taxonomically classified with gtdb-tk v1.5.0.     The sequencing of the V1-V3 region (Allen et al., 2016) of 16S rRNA gene was completed using a custom protocol (F. Escapa et al., 2020) and on the Illumina Mi-Seq platform.     Quality assessment of reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.12.     Data were processed as described in GL-DPPD-7104-A (https://github.com/nasa/GeneLab_Data_Processing/blob/master/Metagenomics/Illumina/Pipeline_GL-DPPD-7107_Versions/GL-DPPD-7107.md), using workflow SW_AmpIllumina v1.0.0 (https://github.com/nasa/GeneLab_Data_Processing/tree/SW_AmpIllumina-A_1.0.0/Amplicon/Illumina/Workflow_Documentation/SW_AmpIllumina-A). Quality assessment of filtered reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.9. Primers were already removed from the submitted raw data. The raw data had 101 bp R1 reads and 401 bp R2 reads. Due to relatively poor quality of the R2 reads, and because for many recovered sequences the paired reads did not span the target amplicon (exploration of this can be found in the general-processing-notes.txt file packaged with in the V1V3-processing_info.zip archive), only the R1 reads were processed – which in this case extended into the V3 region back from the reference 518 position. DADA2 v1.20.0 was utilized for quality-trimming and filtering and inference of amplicon sequence variants (ASVs), and taxonomy was assigned with DECIPHER v2.20 using the SILVA r138 reference database.     The sequencing of the 16S ribosomal RNA gene was then performed as previously described (Tong et al., 2014). The V4 region of the 16S rRNA gene was amplified and barcoded using 515f/806r primers then 2x150bp (paired-end) sequencing was performed on an Illumina HiSeq 2500 platform (Caporaso et al., 2012).     Data were processed as described in GL-DPPD-7104-A (https://github.com/nasa/GeneLab_Data_Processing/blob/master/Metagenomics/Illumina/Pipeline_GL-DPPD-7107_Versions/GL-DPPD-7107.md), using workflow SW_AmpIllumina v1.0.0 (https://github.com/nasa/GeneLab_Data_Processing/tree/SW_AmpIllumina-A_1.0.0/Amplicon/Illumina/Workflow_Documentation/SW_AmpIllumina-A). Quality assessment of filtered reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.9. Primers were already removed from the submitted raw data. DADA2 v1.20.0 was utilized for quality-trimming and filtering and inference of amplicon sequence variants (ASVs), and taxonomy was assigned with DECIPHER v2.20 using the SILVA r138 reference database.     The analysis of the mouse blood serum metabolome targeted three different classes of molecules that each used different sample preparation and LC-MS/MS protocols: regular polar metabolites (Group 1), carbonic acids (Group 2), and glycols (Group 3). All samples were extracted in a randomized order. First, a stock extract for the three downstream methods was prepared by mixing 5 ul mouse blood serum with 20 ul methanol. The mixtures were precipitated at -20 C for 2 hours, 10 min at 20,000  g and 4 C and supernatants were transferred into new Eppendorf tubes. For regular polar metabolites (Group 1), 2.5 ul extract were mixed with 50 ul 0.1 % (v/v) formic acid, centrifuged for 10 min at 20,000 _ g and 4 C, transferred into glass vials, and injected (5 ul) directly into the LC-MS/MS system. Carbonic acids (Group 2) were derivatized using the 2-Hydrazinoquinoline-method established by (Lu et al., 2013). Specifically, 2.5 ul serum extract were mixed with 500 nmol 13C,D4-acetic acid isotope in 50 ul freshly prepared derivatization mix (1 mM 2-hydrazinoquinoline, 1 mM 2,2'-dipyridil disulfide, and 1 mM triphenylphosphine in acetonitrile). The reaction mixture was incubated for 1 h at 60 C, chilled on ice, and quenched with 50 ul H2O. After centrifugation at 20,000  g and 4 C for 5 min, samples were transferred into glass vials and 10 ul aliquots used for LC-MS/MS-analysis. Glycols (Group 3) were prepared according to (Imbert et al., 2014). 2.5 ul blood serum extracts were spiked with 2.5 nmol D4-1,4-butanediol isotope in 7.5 ul water. Then, 10 ul 4 M NaOH were added and mixed with 5 ul benzoyl chloride followed by 5-minute incubation at room temperature. The derivatization reaction was stopped by adding 5 ul 5 % (w/v) glycine. Samples were vortexed, incubates for 5 min and the glycol derivatives extracted with 200 ul propane. Samples were centrifuged for 10 min at 4 C and 20,000  g, supernatants transferred into a fresh Eppendorf tube and evaporated in a SpeedVac to complete dryness. After reconstitution in 50 ul buffer (50 % acetonitrile, 50 % water, 10 mM ammonium formate pH 2.5), insoluble material was removed by centrifugation and 10 ul aliquots subjected to LC-MS/MS analysis.     Targeted quantitation was performed on a SCIEX QTRAP 6500 triple quadrupole mass spectrometer (SCIEX, Framingham, MA, USA) equipped with an Ion Drive Turbo V ESI source and a Shimadzu Nexera XR HPLC system (Shimadzu, Kyoto, Japan). Details of the respective HPLC methods and instrument parameters are summarized in Table S15. For polar metabolites (Group 1), a Poroshell 120 EC-C18 (4.6x100 mm, 2.7 um particle size; Agilent Technologies (Santa Clara, California)) guarded by a Security Guard Ultra C18 precolumn (Phenomenex, Torrance, California) was used for reverse phase separation as described (Schulte et al., 2020). Derivatized carbonic acids were separated using an Acquity UPLC BEH C18 column (2.1x50 mm, 1.7 um particle size; Waters Corporation (Milford, Massachusetts)) hyphenated to a KrudKatcher Ultra HPLC In-Line Filter (0.2 um depth x 0.004 inch) as previously described (Lu et al., 2013). Glycol derivatives were separated using an Atlantis dC18 column (2.1 x 150 mm, 3 um particle size; Waters Corp.) protected by a KrudKatcher Ultra HPLC In-Line Filter (0.2 um depth x 0.004 inch) according to (Imbert et al., 2014). The mass spectrometer was optimized for the detection of each molecule to obtain maximum intensity (polarity, collision energy, precursor and product ion selection). Samples were analyzed in randomized order and quality control standards were injected at regular intervals during and between analysis batches to monitor instrument performance (analyte separation and detection). Calibration standards were prepared by serial-dilution of stock solutions containing 64 compounds for polar metabolites, 4 carbonic acids, and 3 glycols. The carbonic acid and glycol standards were derivatized at the same time as the respective sample batches as described above. Calibration curves were collected over a concentration range of 100,000 to 0.0001 nmol using 5 and 10 uL injection volumes. All stock solutions were aliquoted and stored at -20 C until used.     The objective of the Rodent Research-5 (RR-5) study was to evaluate bone loss in mice under microgravity conditions and to determine if treatment with NELL1 can reduce or prevent bone loss that would otherwise occur in microgravity. Bone loss assessments include measuring a combination of blood markers, micro Computed Tomography (uCT), Dual-energy X-ray Absorptiometry (DXA), and bone histomorphometry. Forty mice (female; BALB/c; 30 weeks old; Taconic), launched in two Transporters (20 mice per), then were transferred to Rodent Habitats onboard the International Space Station (ISS) and maintained in microgravity for ~30 days until Live Animal Return (N of 20; LAR to UCLA) or for ~9 weeks total which were ISS Terminal (N of 20; IT). There was a Baseline of subjects at KSC. A Ground Control group mimicked LAR, which was housed at KSC, then shipped live to UCLA. There was a Ground Control group at KSC which mimicked flight. All animals were kept on a temperature controlled (~28C), 12-hr Light/Dark Cycle. There were two treatment groups: control (saline vehicle [10 mg/kg in 0.3 mls], and experimental NELL1 [10 mg/kg in 0.3 mls]). Alizarin red or calcein green bone label markers were administered as well (respectively 50 mg/kg, 0.1 mls and 20 mg/kg, 0.1 mls). Injections of vehicle, NELL1, and bone markers were intraperitoneal (i.p.).  The mice were injected 6-8 days after launch and at two week (+/- 1day) intervals thereafter. During the first set of injections (L+6-8 days), only NELL1 or vehicle was injected (no bone marker). Two or three treatments were administered to all 40 mice on orbit, depending on Dragon berth duration.  Twenty mice, at just prior to Dragon unberth (Spx-11), were transferred to a Dragon and transported live back to Earth (LAR). An additional two treatments were administered to the 20 mice that remained aboard the ISS. The 20 mice kept aboard the ISS, at ~L+4 to 5 weeks, were anesthetized via i.p. injection of ketamine/xylazine, DXA scanned, and then recovered via injection of atipamazole. At L+9 weeks the ISS mice were anesthetized (Ketamine/xylazine/acepromazine) and DXA scanned. Blood samples were obtained by cardiac puncture through closed chest. Animals were euthanized by exsanguination and cervical dislocation. One hind limb was dissected from each animal and fixed in 10% neutral buffered formalin (NBF). The NBF was removed and replaced with 70% ethanol after 5-6 days of fixation. The blood was separated by centrifugation, and tubes were frozen and stored at -80C or colder. Each carcass was wrapped in aluminum foil and placed in -80C storage or colder until return. All the samples analyzed in this dataset were collected from saline vehicle treated animals.     Fecal Sample collection: Nominally, two freshly harvested fecal samples or more per mouse (in individual, autoclaved cages) were collected and placed in 2.0 mL sterile, nuclease free (RNAase/DNAase), non-pyrogenic, polypropylene Corning Cyrogenic vials. Samples were promptly flash frozen with liquid nitrogen for 15 minutes - one hour (within 15 minutes or less of collection) and stored in a -80C freezer. One fecal pellet (equivalent in mass) was used per mouse for DNA extraction and sequencing of the 16S ribosomal RNA gene was then performed as previously described (Tong et al., 2014). Oral Sample collection: The molars, cheeks and tongue (lingual and buccal) regions of the LAR and LAR_G rodents (3 swabs per mouse within each cage) were used as a consistent anatomical position for oral microbiome sampling. The rodents were anesthetized via isoflurane and sampled. Specifically, Plasdent Maxaplicator Super fine (2 mm) swabs were used for collection (MPN 600-R-2). Plasma serum was isolated as described in (Kwak and Zhang et al. 2022)

_source.Study Publication Title: Specific host metabolite and gut microbiome alterations are associated with bone loss during spaceflight
_source.Study Description: Understanding the axis of the human microbiome and physiological homeostasis is an essential task in managing deep-space travel associated health risks. The NASA led Rodent Research 5 mission enabled an ancillary investigation of the gut microbiome varying exposure to microgravity (flight) relative to ground controls in the context of previously shown bone mineral density (BMD) loss that was observed in these flight groups. We demonstrate elevated abundance of Lactobacillus murinus and Dorea sp. during microgravity exposure relative to ground control through whole genome sequencing and 16S rRNA analyses. Specific functionally assigned gene clusters of Lactobacillus murinus and Dorea sp. capable of producing metabolites, lactic acid, leucine/isoleucine, and glutathione are enriched. These metabolites are elevated in the microgravity-exposed host serum through LC-MS/MS metabolomic analysis. Along with BMD loss, ELISA analysis reveals increases of osteocalcin and reductions in tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase 5b signifying additional loss of bone homeostasis in flight.

_source.Study Title: The Maleth Program: Malta’s first space mission discoveries on the microbiome of diabetic foot ulcers
_source.Study Funding Agency: Institutional Research Funds of Prof Joseph Borg by the University of Malta (Project Maleth); Ministry of Foreign and European Affairs, Government of Malta, Malta; Tertiary Education Scholarship Scheme to Ms Christine Gatt
_source.Study Protocol Description:
10 tissue samples were collected from patients presenting with severe diabetic foot ulcers at Mater Dei Hospital, Malta. These samples were collected aseptically during amputation surgery. 5 biofilm samples were also obtained from patients presenting with less severe diabetic foot ulcers at the Floriana Health Centre, Malta, which is a primary Health Care Facility. The biofilm samples were collected aseptically during ulcer debridement as part of the required treatment. 12 skin swabs were obtained from the abovementioned patients, either on the day of debridement or a day after the amputation surgery. The swab was moistened with Phosphate Buffered Saline (PBS) and an area of the healthy skin from the contralateral foot was swabbed. The inoculated swab was then placed in PBS and transported to the lab for processing. Three patients were not swabbed as they discharged themselves the day after surgery. The six tissue samples that were chosen for Project Maleth were treated in the following way. Each original tissue sample was further cut into two other pieces. One piece was placed in a cuvette and immersed in Phosphate buffered saline. This tissue, which served as the Earth Control tissue sample, was kept in an incubator at 30C for the whole mission duration. This temperature was equivalent to that found on the ISS. The other piece of tissue was placed in another cuvette and immersed in PBS. The six cuvettes containing the tissue samples were mounted on the IceCube and sent to Cape Canaveral for a SpaceX CRS23 re-supply mission. These will be referred to as the ISS tissue samples. Once on the ISS, the tissues remained in orbit for thirty days until they returned back on Earth. After returning back to Earth, both the samples that were sent to ISS and the control samples were kept at 15-18C in Phosphate buffered saline (the solution that they were in during the experiment). Both the ISS and Earth control tissues were kept at this temperature for a month until the ISS samples arrived in our labs in Malta from the USA. Upon arrival at our labs in Malta, the ISS tissue samples as well as the Earth Control tissue samples, were processed for culture and lysed for DNA extraction.     200µl of the lysed tissue/biofilm or 200µl of PBS from the skin swabs were transferred to an Eppendorf tube and placed in the QIACube for DNA extraction using the QIAamp® DNA Mini kit. After DNA extraction, the DNA concentration was measured with Qubit.
Negative control samples were processed in the same way to determine and exclude any reagent contamination. The three negative controls consisted of uninoculated PBS, uninoculated RNase/DNase free water and an uninoculated swab that was vortexed in PBS.     After DNA extraction, the samples were processed for 16S rRNA gene sequencing. The first PCR was performed by taking 10µl of the 20ng of gDNA and performing the following thermal cycling conditions (98 C for 2 minutes, then 30 cycles of 98 C for 10s, 65oC for 20s and 72 C for 20s. The final extension was at 72 C for 2 minutes). The following primers were used; Forward GTGCCAGCMGCCGCGGTAA; Reverse GGACTACHVGGGTWTCTAAT. The Primermix is based on Caparose et al 2011 targeting the V4 region. The second PCR was then performed using the same thermal cycling conditions however, to each different sample a specific barcode tag was added. The samples were then loaded on 1% Agarose gel to check if the samples were amplified to the right size. The samples were then pooled and sample clean-up was performed by magnetic beads. The DNA concentration was then determined again by Qubit and the DNA library was analysed with Agilent Bioanalyzer to determine the size of the basepairs. The band should be between 300-600bp. Finally the pooled DNA library was then denatured and diluted to 4pM. The PhiX library was also denatured and diluted to 4pM.     The amplicon library and the PhiX Control were then combined and loaded into the cartilage. The flowcell and the loaded cartilage were placed in the Illumina MiSeq Next Generation Sequencer for sequencing.     Quality assessment of reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.9. Primers were removed with cutadapt v2.3. DADA2 v1.20.0 was utilized for quality-trimming and filtering and inference of amplicon sequence variants (ASVs), and taxonomy was assigned with DECIPHER v2.20 using the SILVA r138 reference database.
_source.Study Publication Author List: Gatt C  Tierney BT  Madrigal P  Mason CE  Beheshti A  Telzerow A  Benes V  Zahra G  Bonett J  Cassar K  Borg J.
_source.Study Publication Title: The Maleth program: Malta's first space mission discoveries on the microbiome of diabetic foot ulcers.
_source.Study Description: The first mission (Maleth I) forms part of Project Maleth and aims to uncover the effects of spaceflight, microgravity and radiation on human skin tissue microbiome samples from six Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus diabetic foot ulcers (DFU). The mission intended to highlight some of the very best frontier research programs in Malta that capitalized on the unique spectra of medical, life, and health sciences and the power of collaborative research in using multiple tools to answer the research question. Maleth I’s overall objective was achieved in that the specimens conducted to space and back yielded positive growth on testing the microbiome by both standard microbiology techniques and genetic typing using 16S rRNA amplicon sequencing. Preliminary findings of this mission are discussed in light of its innovative approach at DFU microbiome research, and the clinical implications that may emerge from this and other future similar studies.

_source.Project Title: The Role of P21/CDKN1a Pathway in Microgravity-Induced Bone Tissue Regenerative Arrest - A Spaceflight Study of Transgenic P21/CDKN1a Null Mice in Microgravity
_source.Study Funding Agency: The sequencing analysis was funded by the NASA Space Biology program within the NASA Science Mission Directorate's (SMD) Biological and Physical Sciences (BPS) Division.
_source.Study Protocol Description: Twenty (20) mice (female, 10 B6129SF2/J Wild Type (WT) and 10 B6;129S2-Cdkn1atm1Tyj/J (p21-null), 14-15 weeks old) were launched in one Transporter on SpaceX-21 (SpX-21) on December 6, 2020. The Flight (FL) mice were transferred into two Rodent Habitats upon arrival to the International Space Station (ISS) and were maintained in microgravity for 28-29 days. At 7 days before euthanasia (December 26 and 27, 2020), all 20 mice received an intraperitoneal (IP) injection with the bone formation marker (Calcein). At about 48 +/- 2 hours before euthanasia (December 31, 2020 and January 1, 2021), all 20 mice received an IP injection with a second dose of Calcein as well as the cell proliferation marker (BrdU). At approximately 28-29 days in microgravity (January 2 and 3, 2021), the Flight mice were euthanized with a Ketamine/Xylazine cocktail, followed by cardiac puncture and thoracotomy. Following skin removal, both hindlimb quarters were removed and preserved or fixed. Each carcass was wrapped in aluminum foil, preserved in the CryoChiller, and stored at -80C or colder until return to PI. Two other groups of mice, 20 for Ground Control (GC) and 24 for Vivarium Control (VIV), half B6129SF/J Wild Type (WT) and half B6;129S2-Cdkn1atm1Tyj/J (p21-null), were selected by the PI and underwent the same procedures and treatment as the Flight group but with an offset of 3 days. In addition to the IP injections (Calcein and BrdU) described above, all mice in the FL, GC, and VIV groups also received a pre-flight subcutaneous injection of the bone marker (Alizarin Red). Twenty (20) female mice (half WT and half p21-null) were selected by the PI for the Baseline Control (BL) group. Following a successful Launch, baseline animals were injected with Calcein at the time of Launch (7 days prior to dissection) and at 48 +/- 2 hours before dissection. BL animals were also injected with BrdU at 48 +/- 2 hours before dissection. Baseline dissections were performed 7 days after launch following the same procedures used for the Flight animals.     At the end of RR-10 experiment, all frozen carcasses and preserved hindlimbs were returned to the PI. In May 2021, the Biospecimen Sharing Program (BSP) team performed complex, integrated dissections at NASA Ames Research Center with the Principal Investigator team. On the day of the dissection, mouse carcasses were thawed by bringing the carcass out of -80C preservation to room temperature and keeping the carcass in RT for 40 minutes. Once the mouse carcass was thawed enough to manipulate, the dissection started and various tissues were collected. The digestive system was collected from the mouse carcass and transferred on a clean weighting boat to a secondary dissector. Fecal samples were extruded from the colon by creating a small incision in the colon tissue and taking the pellets out using blunt tweezers. Fecal pellets were put in to the preservation tubes and preserved. On average, fecal samples were collected ~11 minutes after dissection began.     DNA was extracted using the Maxwell RSC Purefood GMO and Authentication Kit (Promega, Madison, WI). Half to whole frozen fecal pellet was placed into a tube with 940 uL CTAB solution and homogenized using tissue homogenizing bead mix (Navy RINO Lysis, Next Advance) on Bullet Blender Gold 24 (Next Advance) for 3 minutes at 4C. Homogenates were centrifuged for 3 minutes at 10C and 21,000 g to deflate foam. The supernatant from each sample was then used to isolate and purify DNA following the manufacturer's protocol. DNA was eluted in 75 uL RNAse free H2O and was further cleaned using OneStep PCR Inhibitor Removal Kit (Zymo Research). Concentrations for all DNA samples were measured using Qubit 3.0 Fluorometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA) with Qubit DNA HS kit. DNA quality and size were assessed using the Agilent 4200 TapeStation with Agilent gDNA ScreenTape Kit (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA).     DNA library was prepared with the Illumina DNA Prep Library kit (Illumina, San Diego, CA) by GeneLab Sample Processing Lab. Input DNA were approximately ~500 ng. Index adapters were IDT for Illumina, 96-well Illumina RNA/ DNA Unique Dual Index Adapters, Set A and Set B. 5 cycles PCR were performed. Library fragment size ~550 bp was assessed using Agilent 4200 TapeStation with D1000 DNA ScreenTape (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA).  Concentrations for all DNA samples were measured using Qubit 3.0 Fluorometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA) with Qubit DNA HS kit.  Library quality control was performed on iSeq100 (Illumina, San Diego, CA).     DNA sequencing was performed by GeneLab Sample Processing Lab on Illumina NovaSeq 6000. Paired end 250bp. PhiX included as control.     Utilizing kraken2 v2.1.1, a human genome reference database was constructed from NCBI's RefSeq (GCF_000001405.39) GRCh38.p13, with --no-masking, and defaults of kmer-length 35 and minimizer-length of 31. FASTQ files were screened against this database, and all successfully classified reads were removed.     Utilizing kraken2 v2.1.1, a mouse genome reference database was constructed from NCBI's RefSeq (GCF_000001635.27) GRCm39, with --no-masking, and defaults of kmer-length 35 and minimizer-length of 31. FASTQ files were screened against this database, and all successfully classified reads were counted and reported as a percentage of the total.     Quality assessment of reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.11. Quality-trimming and filtering was performed with bbmap v38.86. Read-based processing was performed with humann v3.6. Individual samples were assembled with megahit v1.2.9. Genes were called with prodigal v2.6.3. Taxonomic classification of genes and contigs was performed with CAT v5.2.2. Functional annotation was done with KOFamScan v1.3.0. Reads were mapped to assemblies with bowtie2 v2.3.5.1, and coverage information was extracted for reads and contigs with samtools v1.9 and bbmap v38.86. Binning of contigs was performed with metabat2 v2.15. Bins were summarized with bit v1.8.53 and estimates of quality were generated with checkm v1.1.3. High-quality bins (greater than 90% est. completeness and less than 10% est. redundancy) were taxonomically classified with gtdb-tk v1.5.0.
_source.Study Description: The objective of the Rodent Research-10 Mission (RR-10) was to investigate how spaceflight affects the cellular and molecular mechanisms of normal bone tissue regeneration in space. To this end, ten (10) 14-15 weeks-old female B6129SF2/J Wild Type (WT), and ten (10) 14-15 weeks-old female B6;129S2-Cdkn1atm1Tyj/J (p21-null) mice received a pre-flight subcutaneous injection of the bone marker (Alizarin Red), and were then delivered to the ISS aboard SpaceX-21. At 7 days before euthanasia, all 20 mice received an intraperitoneal (IP) injection with a bone formation marker (Calcein). At 48 +/- 2 hours before euthanasia, all 20 mice received an IP injection with a second dose of Calcein as well as a cell proliferation marker (BrdU). Then, following 28-29 days in microgravity, the Flight mice were euthanized. Following removal of hindlimbs, carcasses were wrapped in aluminum foil, preserved in the CryoChiller, and stored at -80 C or colder until return to Earth. In addition to the Flight group, three ground control groups were also part of the study: Basal (representing the pre-launch state), Vivarium (standard vivarium housing for the same duration of time as flight), and Ground (flight habitat in the International Space Station Environment Simulator, ISSES). Twenty mice (10 of each strain) were included in each of these control groups (except Vivarium which included 12 of each strain). These were treated, euthanized and processed on the same schedule and in the same manner as the flight samples. At the end of RR-10 experiment, all frozen carcasses were partially thawed and fecal pellets were removed and preserved by flash freezing in LN2. DNA was extracted, shotgun metagenome libraries generated, and libraries sequenced (target 10 M clusters at PE 250 bp). This dataset features WT samples from the Flight (n=3), Ground (n=5), Basal (n=10) and Vivarium groups (n=12), as well as p21-null samples from Flight (n=5), Ground (n=5), Basal (n=10) and Vivarium groups (n=12).

_source.Study Protocol Description: Twenty (20) mice (male, C57BL/6J, 16-17 weeks old) were launched in one Transporter on SpaceX-21 (SpX-21) on December 6, 2020. The Flight mice were transferred into two Rodent Habitats upon arrival to the International Space Station (ISS) and were maintained in microgravity for 38 days. The Flight mice were transferred into a Transporter and returned to Earth for Live Animal Return (LAR) on SpX-21 (January 13th, 2021). After Atlantic Ocean splashdown, the LAR Flight mice were transported via helicopter to Kennedy Space Center. Collectively, 20 Flight, 20 HGC, and 20 VGC mice were transferred from Rodent Transporters (Flight and HGC) or vivarium cages (VGC) and placed into shipping containers. All 60 mice were flown via charter plane to the PI’s institution, Texas A and M University (TAMU). All post-flight euthanasia and dissections were performed by the PI team at TAMU. The original plan was to perform all pre-flight and post-flight activities at Roskamp Institute in Sarasota, Florida. Due to the health risks associated with travel during the COVID-19 pandemic, HRP approved all post-flight activities at TAMU, which significantly decreased or eliminated travel for the PI, BSP, and Payload Developer (PD) teams. Upon arrival at the TAMU Animal Care Facility (ACF), the mice underwent post-flight procedures, followed by euthanasia and tissue collection by the PI team.     Fecal pellets were gently pushed out of the descending colon with forceps.  If necessary, colon was wet with saline with a saline wipe before fecal pellets were pushed out using the flat side of the forceps. GeneLab processed 9 samples each from flight/ground control/vivarium control groups in this dataset.     DNA was extracted using the Maxwell RSC Purefood GMO and Authentication Kit (Promega, Madison, WI). Half to whole frozen fecal pellet was placed into a tube with 940 uL CTAB solution and homogenized using tissue homogenizing bead mix (Navy RINO Lysis, Next Advance) on Bullet Blender Gold 24 (Next Advance) for 3 minutes at 4C. Homogenates were centrifuged for 3 minutes at 10C and 21,000 g to deflate foam. The supernatant from each sample was then used to isolate and purify DNA following the manufacturer's protocol. DNA was eluted in 75 uL RNAse free H2O and was further cleaned using OneStep PCR Inhibitor Removal Kit (Zymo Research). Concentrations for all DNA samples were measured using Qubit 3.0 Fluorometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA) with Qubit DNA HS kit. DNA quality and size were assessed using the Agilent 4200 TapeStation with Agilent gDNA ScreenTape Kit (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA).     DNA library was prepared with the Illumina DNA Prep Tagmentation kit (Illumina, San Diego, CA) by GeneLab Sample Processing Lab. Input DNA were approximately ~500 ng. Index adapters were IDT for Illumina, 96-well Illumina RNA/ DNA Unique Dual Index Adapters, Set A and Set B. 5 cycles PCR were performed. Library fragment size ~550 bp was assessed using Agilent 4200 TapeStation with D1000 DNA ScreenTape (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA).  Concentrations for all DNA samples were measured using Qubit 3.0 Fluorometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA) with Qubit DNA HS kit.  Library quality control was performed on iSeq100 (Illumina, San Diego, CA).     DNA sequencing was performed by GeneLab Sample Processing Lab on Illumina NovaSeq 6000. Paired end 250bp. PhiX included as control.     Utilizing kraken2 v2.1.1, a human genome reference database was constructed from NCBI's RefSeq (GCF_000001405.39) GRCh38.p13, with --no-masking, and defaults of kmer-length 35 and minimizer-length of 31. FASTQ files were screened against this database, and all successfully classified reads were removed.     Utilizing kraken2 v2.1.1, a mouse genome reference database was constructed from NCBI's RefSeq (GCF_000001635.27) GRCm39, with --no-masking, and defaults of kmer-length 35 and minimizer-length of 31. FASTQ files were screened against this database, and all successfully classified reads were counted and reported as a percentage of the total.     Raw fastq file quality was evaluated with FastQC (version 0.11.9) and MultiQC (version 1.11) was used to generate MultiQC reports.     Quality assessment of reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.11. Quality-trimming and filtering was performed with bbmap v38.86. Read-based processing was performed with humann v3.6. Individual samples were assembled with megahit v1.2.9. Genes were called with prodigal v2.6.3. Binning of contigs was performed with metabat2 v2.15. Bins were summarized with bit v1.8.53 and estimates of quality were generated with checkm v1.1.3. High-quality bins (greater than 90% est. completeness and less than 10% est. redundancy) were taxonomically classified with gtdb-tk v1.5.0.
_source.Study Description: The objective of the RR-23 mission was to better understand the effects of spaceflight on the eyes, specifically on the structure and function of the arteries, veins, and lymphatic vessels that are needed to maintain vision. To this end, twenty male, C57BL/6J, 16-17 weeks-old mice were delivered to the ISS on SpaceX-21 in a single transporter, transferred to two rodent habitats, and maintained in microgravity for 38 days. Flight mice were then returned to Earth alive (Jan 13th, 2021). After splashdown in the Atlantic Ocean, mice were transported to Kennedy Space Center via helicopter. The 20 Flight, 20 Habitat Ground Control (HGC), and 20 Vivarium Ground Control (VGC) mice were removed from Rodent Transporters (Flight and HGC) or vivarium cages (VGC), placed into shipping containers, and flown to Texas A and M University. There, mice underwent post-flight procedures, before euthanasia and tissue collection. Flight, HGC and VGC animals were euthanized and dissected on Jan 14th, 17th or 20th of 2021, respectively. Feces were removed from the animals and preserved by flash freezing in liquid nitrogen and stored at -80 ˚C until DNA was extracted, and libraries generated and sequenced (target 10 M clusters per sample, PE 250 bp). This dataset features 9 samples from the Flight group, 9 samples from the HGC group, and 9 samples from the VGC group.

_source.Study Protocol Description: Surface sample collections were conducted using pre-moistened sterile polyester wipes (23 cm x 23 cm; ITW Texwipe, Mahwah, NJ) that were placed in a sterile Ziploc bag. Samples were collected from 8 habitable locations around the ISS during early flight for Flight 4 (F4) and mid-flight on Flight 5 (F5). Collected samples were stored at 4C prior to return.     Samples were processed and concentrated using the InnovaPrep concentration pipettor and divided into two aliquots, one treated with PMA to analyze intact cells, and one not treated with Propidium monoazide (PMA). DNA extraction was performed seperately on the PMA and non-PMA treated samples using the Maxwell 16 System (Promega, Madison, WI) in accordance with the instructions provided by the manufacturer.     DNA libraries were prepared for sequencing using the Nextera Flex DNA Library Preparation Kit (20018705, Illumina). Quality and fragment size were assessed on the Agilent Tapestation 4200 (Agilent, Santa Clara, CA). Libraries were quantitate using the Qubit fluorimeter (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA) and normalized to equivalent DNA quantities where possible, pooled, and diluted according to the manufacturer's standard recommendations.     The Illumina NextSeq 500 was used to shotgun metagenomic sequencing with the NextSeq 500/550 300 cycle High Output Sequencing Kit v2.5 (Catalog number 20024908, Illumina, San Diego, CA), using 150 base pair, paired-end reads.     The metagenomic sequencing data from the ISS surface samples were analyzed using the Livermore Metagenomics Analysis Toolkit (LMAT version 1.2.4b with the April 4 2014 LMAT Grand reference database). Reads mapping to the genus Homo or descendant lineages by LMAT were removed. LMAT score threshold = 0.5.     Utilizing kraken2 v2.1.1, a human genome reference database was constructed from NCBI's RefSeq (GCF_000001405.39) GRCh38.p13, with --no-masking, and defaults of kmer-length 35 and minimizer-length of 31. FASTQ files were screened against this database, and all successfully classified reads were removed.     Fastq format was checked with fastq_utils v0.25.1. Quality assessment of reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.12.     Quality assessment of reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.11. Quality-trimming and filtering was performed with bbmap v38.86. Read-based processing was performed with humann v3.6. Individual samples were assembled with megahit v1.2.9. Genes were called with prodigal v2.6.3. Taxonomic classification of genes and contigs was performed with CAT v5.2.2. Functional annotation was done with KOFamScan v1.3.0. Reads were mapped to assemblies with bowtie2 v2.3.5.1, and coverage information was extracted for reads and contigs with samtools v1.9 and bbmap v38.86. Binning of contigs was performed with metabat2 v2.15. Bins were summarized with bit v1.8.53 and estimates of quality were generated with checkm v1.1.3. High-quality bins (greater than 90% est. completeness and less than 10% est. redundancy) were taxonomically classified with gtdb-tk v1.5.0.

_source.Study Publication Title: Crewmember microbiome may influence microbial composition of ISS habitable surfaces
_source.Study Description: This study investigated the interplay between the microbial community of the International Space Station and its crew. Environmental samples were collected from 8 habitable locations around the ISS. The microbial composition was measured using shotgun metagenomic sequencing and procesed using the Livermore Metagenomics Analysis Toolkit.

_source.Study Title: Microbiological and nutritional analysis of lettuce crops grown on the International Space Station-VEG03A
_source.Project Title: 'Veggie' Vegetable Production System Proof of Concept Flight
_source.Study Funding Agency: Funding was provided by NASA's Space Life and Physical Sciences (SLPS) Space Biology Program
_source.Study Protocol Description: VEG 03A experiment plants were harvested at two separate dates, Dec 9, 2016 and Dec 28, 2016 as a cut and come again study. Plant leaves were wrapped in aluminum foil and placed in -80C (MELFI) until return. Two plant pillows with root material from each experiment were also frozen at -80C until return. Parallel ground experiments were handled and sampled identical to flight with a 72 hour delay. The final harvest was processed for 16S microbial characterization. This dataset only includes samples harvested on Dec 28, 2016.     Temperature was maintained during the return of tissues to Kennedy Space Center, where they were also maintained at -80C until processing. Plant leaf material was processed immediately upon thawing and pillows containing roots were thawed at 4 - 8C overnight before sampling was completed. All leaf material from the final harvest was divided for chemical, microbiological and molecular analysis. DNA was extracted from plant leaf and root material of the Veggie pillows using the Microbial Cell DNA Isolation Kit (Qiagen, Inc, Carlsbad, CA) then quantified using the Qubit 2.0 double stranded DNA assays (Invitrogen, Grand Island, NY).     The variable 4 region of the 16S ribosomal RNA gene (rRNA) was selected as a phylogenetic markers to identify microorganisms taxonomically to the species level. A dual indexing system for multiplexing was adapted for these communities and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) was optimized for reagent concentrations and volume. Each community was labeled with two barcoded primers for identification at completion of sequencing. Amplicons were created in triplicate using 1 ng of template DNA in each reaction. After PCR all amplicons were purified using the Min-Elute System (Qiagen, Carlsbad, CA) and quantified with the Qubit 2.0 high sensitivity ds DNA assay (Invitrogen, Grand Island, NY).     The purified amplicons were then pooled in an equimolar concentration to create the library following Illumina protocols. The sample library was combined with a 10% Phi-X control library to create diversity and sequenced on the Illumina MiSeq using a V2 500-cycle kit (Illumina, Inc, San Diego, CA).     Quality assessment of reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.9. Primers were removed with cutadapt v2.3. DADA2 v1.20.0 was utilized for quality-trimming and filtering and inference of amplicon sequence variants (ASVs), and taxonomy was assigned with DECIPHER v2.20 using the SILVA r138 reference database.     Plants were grown in Veggie pillows containing solid, porous, arcillite (calcined clay) substrate in two different blends, Blend 1: 100% sized to 600 u1 mm or Blend 2: a 1:1 ratio of that size to 1–2 mm (Turface Proleague, Profile Products, LLC) and controlled release fertilizer (Nutricote 18-6-8, type 180, Florikan, Sarasota, FL, United States). Procedures for detailed substrate and pillow preparation are outlined in Massa et al. (2017b). Two surface sanitized seeds were attached with guar in each plant pillow between paired germination wicks. All plant rooting pillows with attached seeds were kept dry in heat sealed, gas-impermeable Tedlar bags until test initiation on the ISS. Seeds for three separate, independent plantings (biological replicates) were germinated and grown for 33–56 days on ISS and ground controls were run in controlled environment chambers under ISS environmental conditions with a 24 h delay for VEG-01A and B and a 72 h delay for VEG-03A. Each experiment began with six rooting pillows. Germinated seeds were thinned to one plant per pillow at day 7. Each independent planting was grown at different times aboard ISS with parallel ground experiments for comparison. VEG-01A was grown from May 8 to June 10, 2014; VEG-01B was grown from July 8 to August 10, 2015, and VEG-03A was grown from October 25 to December 28, 2016. VEG-01A and B were harvested after 33 days of growth using sanitized scissors to remove the leaves (Table 1). VEG-03A leaves were harvested sequentially starting at 33 days followed by 3 weekly harvests. Harvested leaves from each plant were wrapped in foil and placed into a −80°C freezer. The first, third, and half of the fourth harvests were consumed by the crew. Only the 2nd harvest and the remaining leaves (approximately half of the total leaves) of the final harvest from VEG-03A were stored for sample return. After completion of the final harvest for all three plantings, two rooting pillows from each independent experiment were removed from Veggie hardware and placed into bags and frozen at −80°C. Ground control samples were processed and stored the same as flight samples. The Veggie baseplate was positioned 30.5–31.75 cm below the LED light array to provide approximately 200 micromole per square meter per second of photosynthetically active radiation at the surface of the pillows in the center of the Veggie unit at a ratio of 12 red (630 nm): 3 Blue (455 nm): 1 green (530 nm). A photoperiod was set to 16 h light/8 h dark. Both the VEG-01A and part of the VEG-03A experiment on ISS had data collected inside the Veggie chamber using a temperature and relative humidity data logger.     The absorbed dose of ionizing radiation received by biological payloads on the International Space Station (ISS) depends on a number of factors, including date and duration of exposure and location of the payload on the ISS. Some of the factors that lead to variations in the absorbed dose rate in orbit are ISS altitude, period during the solar cycle, and location of the sample—the ISS module and the specific location within that module. Shielding effects from the biological payload container or habitat have not been taken into account. The measured absorbed dose can vary based on the dosimetry instrument(s) used. Radiation monitoring on the ISS is not standardized across modules; each international partner has its own suite of instruments, with differing technologies, sensitivities and analysis methodologies, including criteria for distinguishing between lightly ionizing particles (mainly protons) and highly ionizing particles (mainly galactic cosmic ray nuclei). Both active and passive dosimeters are used. Active dosimeters are powered and data are read out and stored and/or telemetered to ground. Some active dosimeters provide additional levels of detail such as time resolution, energy deposition and particle identification. Passive dosimeters are unpowered, record constantly and are read out upon return to the ground. The dose in the metadata is the dose recorded by the radiation detector closest to the sample. In most cases that detector will be in the same ISS module; in cases where data from a detector in the same module are not available, the dose is extrapolated using data from periods where data are available from detectors in multiple modules, including the module containing the payload. The duration of the experiment is defined as the time in space during which the specimen was “living”, including the time on the delivery vehicle (e.g. SpaceX Dragon). Once the specimen was frozen or fixed, the experiment was considered stopped. Details of ISS dosimetry and a table with doses for all GeneLab ISS experiment ISS datasets are available at https://genelab.nasa.gov/environmental/radiation.

_source.Study Publication Title: Microbiological and nutritional analysis of lettuce crops grown on the International Space Station     Plant Pillow Preparation for the Veggie Plant Growth System on the International Space Station
_source.Study Description: The ability to grow safe, fresh food to supplement packaged foods of astronauts in space has been an important goal for NASA. Food crops grown in space experience different environmental conditions than plants grown on Earth (e.g., reduced gravity, elevated radiation levels). To study the effects of space conditions, red romaine lettuce, Lactuca sativa cv ‘Outredgeous,’ plants were grown in Veggie plant growth chambers on the International Space Station (ISS) and compared with ground-grown plants. Multiple plantings were grown on ISS and harvested using either a single, final harvest, or sequential harvests in which several mature leaves were removed from the plants at weekly intervals. Ground controls were grown simultaneously with a 24–72 h delay using ISS environmental data. Food safety of the plants was determined by heterotrophic plate counts for bacteria and fungi, as well as isolate identification using samples taken from the leaves and roots. Molecular characterization was conducted using Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) to provide taxonomic composition and phylogenetic structure of the community. Leaves were also analyzed for elemental composition, as well as levels of phenolics, anthocyanins, and Oxygen Radical Absorbance Capacity (ORAC). Comparison of flight and ground tissues showed some differences in total counts for bacteria and yeast/molds (2.14 – 4.86 log10 CFU/g), while screening for select human pathogens yielded negative results. Bacterial and fungal isolate identification and community characterization indicated variation in the diversity of genera between leaf and root tissue with diversity being higher in root tissue, and included differences in the dominant genera. The only difference between ground and flight experiments was seen in the third experiment, VEG-03A, with significant differences in the genera from leaf tissue. Flight and ground tissue showed differences in Fe, K, Na, P, S, and Zn content and total phenolic levels, but no differences in anthocyanin and ORAC levels. This study indicated that leafy vegetable crops can produce safe, edible, fresh food to supplement to the astronauts’ diet, and provide baseline data for continual operation of the Veggie plant growth units on ISS.

_source.Study Protocol Description: Temperature was maintained during the return of tissues to Kennedy Space Center, where they were also maintained at -80C until processing. Plant leaf material was processed immediately upon thawing and pillows containing roots were thawed at 4 - 8C overnight before sampling was completed. All leaf material was divided for chemical, microbiological and molecular analysis. DNA was extracted from plant leaf and root material of the Veggie pillows using the Microbial Cell DNA Isolation Kit (Qiagen, Inc, Carlsbad, CA) then quantified using the Qubit 2.0 double stranded DNA assays (Invitrogen, Grand Island, NY). DNA was extracted from plant leaf and root material of the Veggie pillows using the Microbial Cell DNA Isolation Kit (Qiagen, Inc, Carlsbad, CA) then quantified using the Qubit 2.0 double stranded DNA assays (Invitrogen, Grand Island, NY).     The variable 4 region of the 16S ribosomal RNA gene (rRNA) was selected as a phylogenetic markers to identify microorganisms taxonomically to the species level. A dual indexing system for multiplexing was adapted for these communities and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) was optimized for reagent concentrations and volume. Each community was labeled with two barcoded primers for identification at completion of sequencing. Amplicons were created in triplicate using 1 ng of template DNA in each reaction. After PCR all amplicons were purified using the Min-Elute System (Qiagen, Carlsbad, CA) and quantified with the Qubit 2.0 high sensitivity ds DNA assay (Invitrogen, Grand Island, NY).     The purified amplicons were then pooled in an equimolar concentration to create the library following Illumina protocols. The sample library was combined with a 10% Phi-X control library to create diversity and sequenced on the Illumina MiSeq using a V2 500-cycle kit (Illumina, Inc, San Diego, CA).     Fastq format was checked with fastq_utils v0.25.1. Quality assessment of reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.12.     Data were processed as described in GL-DPPD-7104-A (https://github.com/nasa/GeneLab_Data_Processing/blob/master/Amplicon/Illumina/Pipeline_GL-DPPD-7104_Versions/GL-DPPD-7104-A.md), using workflow SW_AmpIllumina v1.1.1 (https://github.com/nasa/GeneLab_Data_Processing/tree/SW_AmpIllumina-A_1.1.1/Amplicon/Illumina/Workflow_Documentation/SW_AmpIllumina-A). Quality assessment of reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.9.  Primers were already removed from the submitted raw data. DADA2 v1.20.0 was utilized for quality-trimming and filtering and inference of amplicon sequence variants (ASVs), and taxonomy was assigned with DECIPHER v2.20 using the SILVA r138 reference database. Reverse read quality was very poor, so the data were processed using the forward reads only.     Plants were grown in Veggie pillows containing solid, porous, arcillite (calcined clay) substrate in two different blends, Blend 1: 100% sized to 600 u1 mm or Blend 2: a 1:1 ratio of that size to 1–2 mm (Turface Proleague, Profile Products, LLC) and controlled release fertilizer (Nutricote 18-6-8, type 180, Florikan, Sarasota, FL, United States). Procedures for detailed substrate and pillow preparation are outlined in Massa et al. (2017b). Two surface sanitized seeds were attached with guar in each plant pillow between paired germination wicks. All plant rooting pillows with attached seeds were kept dry in heat sealed, gas-impermeable Tedlar bags until test initiation on the ISS. Seeds for three separate, independent plantings (biological replicates) were germinated and grown for 33–56 days on ISS and ground controls were run in controlled environment chambers under ISS environmental conditions with a 24 h delay for VEG-01A and B and a 72 h delay for VEG-03A. Each experiment began with six rooting pillows. Germinated seeds were thinned to one plant per pillow at day 7. Each independent planting was grown at different times aboard ISS with parallel ground experiments for comparison. VEG-01A was grown from May 8 to June 10, 2014; VEG-01B was grown from July 8 to August 10, 2015, and VEG-03A was grown from October 25 to December 28, 2016. VEG-01A and B were harvested after 33 days of growth using sanitized scissors to remove the leaves. Ground control samples were processed and stored the same as flight samples. The Veggie baseplate was positioned 30.5–31.75 cm below the LED light array to provide approximately 200 micromole per square meter per second of photosynthetically active radiation at the surface of the pillows in the center of the Veggie unit at a ratio of 12 red (630 nm): 3 Blue (455 nm): 1 green (530 nm). A photoperiod was set to 16 h light/8 h dark.     At the completion of the VEG-01 experiments plants were harvested. Plant leaves were wrapped in aluminum foil and placed in -80C (MELFI) until return. Two plant pillows with root material from each experiment were also frozen at -80C until return. Parallel ground experiments were handled and sampled identical to flight with a 24 hour delay.     The Internal Transcribed Spacer (ITS) region was selected as a phylogenetic marker to identify fungi taxonomically to the species level. A dual indexing system for multiplexing was adapted for these communities and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) was optimized for reagent concentrations and volume. Each community was labeled with two barcoded primers for identification at completion of sequencing. Amplicons were created in triplicate using 1 ng of template DNA in each reaction. After PCR all amplicons were purified using the Min-Elute System (Qiagen, Carlsbad, CA) and quantified with the Qubit 2.0 high sensitivity ds DNA assay (Invitrogen, Grand Island, NY).     Data were processed as described in GL-DPPD-7104-A (https://github.com/nasa/GeneLab_Data_Processing/blob/master/Amplicon/Illumina/Pipeline_GL-DPPD-7104_Versions/GL-DPPD-7104-A.md), using workflow SW_AmpIllumina v1.1.1 (https://github.com/nasa/GeneLab_Data_Processing/tree/SW_AmpIllumina-A_1.1.1/Amplicon/Illumina/Workflow_Documentation/SW_AmpIllumina-A). Quality assessment of reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.9.  Primers were trimmed with cutadapt v2.3. DADA2 v1.20.0 was utilized for quality-trimming and filtering and inference of amplicon sequence variants (ASVs), and taxonomy was assigned with DECIPHER v2.20 using the UNITE v2020 database.

Plants were grown in Veggie pillows containing solid, porous, arcillite (calcined clay) substrate in two different blends, Blend 1: 100% sized to 600 u1 mm or Blend 2: a 1:1 ratio of that size to 1–2 mm (Turface Proleague, Profile Products, LLC) and controlled release fertilizer (Nutricote 18-6-8, type 180, Florikan, Sarasota, FL, United States). Procedures for detailed substrate and pillow preparation are outlined in Massa et al. (2017b). All plant rooting pillows with attached seeds were kept dry in heat sealed, gas-impermeable Tedlar bags until test initiation on the ISS. Seeds for three separate, independent plantings (biological replicates) were germinated and grown for 33–56 days on ISS and ground controls were run in controlled environment chambers under ISS environmental conditions with a 24 h delay for VEG-01A and B and a 72 h delay for VEG-03A. VEG-01A was grown from May 8 to June 10, 2014; VEG-01B was grown from July 8 to August 10, 2015, and VEG-03A was grown from October 25 to December 28, 2016. VEG-01A and B were harvested after 33 days of growth using sanitized scissors to remove the leaves (Table 1). VEG-03A leaves were harvested sequentially starting at 33 days followed by 3 weekly harvests. Harvested leaves from each plant were wrapped in foil and placed into a −80°C freezer. The first, third, and half of the fourth harvests were consumed by the crew. Only the 2nd harvest and the remaining leaves (approximately half of the total leaves) of the final harvest from VEG-03A were stored for sample return. After completion of the final harvest for all three plantings, two rooting pillows from each independent experiment were removed from Veggie hardware and placed into bags and frozen at −80°C. Ground control samples were processed and stored the same as flight samples. A photoperiod was set to 16 h light/8 h dark. Both the VEG-01A and part of the VEG-03A experiment on ISS had data collected inside the Veggie chamber using a temperature and relative humidity data logger.     Quality assessment of reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.9. Primers were removed with cutadapt v2.3. DADA2 v1.20.0 was utilized for quality-trimming and filtering and inference of amplicon sequence variants (ASVs), and taxonomy was assigned with DECIPHER v2.20.0 using the SILVA r138 reference database for 16S samples and the UNITE v2020 reference database for ITS samples.

_source.Study Publication Title: Microbiological and Nutritional Analysis of Lettuce Crops Grown on the International Space Station
_source.Study Description: The ability to grow safe, fresh food to supplement packaged foods of astronauts in space has been an important goal for NASA. Food crops grown in space experience different environmental conditions than plants grown on Earth (e.g., reduced gravity, elevated radiation levels). To study the effects of space conditions, red romaine lettuce, Lactuca sativa cv ‘Outredgeous,’ plants were grown in Veggie plant growth chambers on the International Space Station (ISS) and compared with ground-grown plants. Multiple plantings were grown on ISS and harvested using either a single, final harvest, or sequential harvests in which several mature leaves were removed from the plants at weekly intervals. Ground controls were grown simultaneously with a 24–72 h delay using ISS environmental data. Food safety of the plants was determined by heterotrophic plate counts for bacteria and fungi, as well as isolate identification using samples taken from the leaves and roots. Molecular characterization was conducted using Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) to provide taxonomic composition and phylogenetic structure of the community. Leaves were also analyzed for elemental composition, as well as levels of phenolics, anthocyanins, and Oxygen Radical Absorbance Capacity (ORAC). Comparison of flight and ground tissues showed some differences in total counts for bacteria and yeast/molds (2.14 – 4.86 log10 CFU/g), while screening for select human pathogens yielded negative results. Bacterial and fungal isolate identification and community characterization indicated variation in the diversity of genera between leaf and root tissue with diversity being higher in root tissue, and included differences in the dominant genera. The only difference between ground and flight experiments was seen in the third experiment, VEG-03A, with significant differences in the genera from leaf tissue. Flight and ground tissue showed differences in Fe, K, Na, P, S, and Zn content and total phenolic levels, but no differences in anthocyanin and ORAC levels. This study indicated that leafy vegetable crops can produce safe, edible, fresh food to supplement to the astronauts’ diet, and provide baseline data for continual operation of the Veggie plant growth units on ISS.

_source.Study Protocol Description: A cohort of 36 weeks-old female C57BL/6 mice (Taconic Biosciences) were flown to the ISS and were housed in the Rodent Habitat. Half of the mice were subjected to microgravity for ~30 days and returned to earth alive before euthanization (Live Animal Return, LAR). The other half were subjected to microgravity for 52-55 days before euthanzing on ISS (Iss-Terminal, ISS-T).  All the animals from which the samples were processed in this dataset were operated to insert an implantable subcutaneous nanochannel delivery system prior to launch to deliver sham treatment. The cocktail included Propylene glycol (20%v/v), 1N HCL (10%v/v), Solutol HS 15 (10%v/v), 1N NaOH (5%v/v), PBS (12.5%v/v), and water (42.5%v/v).  The study followed recommendations in the Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals and the protocol (Protocol number RR6) was approved on Oct. 24, 2017 by the NASA Flight Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).     After ~30 days in microgravity, half of the mice returned to earth alive (LAR FLT) and were euthanized by Isoflurane inhalation and were dissected immediately at Novartis Facilities.  The other half of mice were euthanized on ISS (ISS-T FLT) by intraperitoneal injection of ketamine/xylazine/acepromazine after ~60 days in microgravity. Following blood draw and hind limb dissection, the carcasses were wrapped in aluminum foil, placed in a ziploc bag and placed in storage at -80C or colder until return to earth and dissected at Houston at a later date.  There were two Basal (BSL) groups of animals sacrificed (LAR BSL & ISS-T BSL) at Kennedy Space Center. A Ground Control group, LAR GC, mimicked the LAR FLT group, which was housed at KSC, then shipped alive to Novartis Facilities, where both the LAR FLT and LAR GC groups were processed.  The ISS-T Ground Controls (ISS-T GC), housed at KSC, followed the same euthanasia timeline, methods, and preservation of the ISS-Terminal Flight. The final dissection of frozen 60-day ISS-T FLT, frozen 60-day ISS-T GC and 0-day ISS-T BSl animals were completed at Houston Methodist Research Institute, in Houston, Texas. For all ISS-T groups, on the day of dissection, the frozen carcasses were removed from -80C freezer and placed in 4C fridge for thawing prior to dissection.  Multiple tissues were collected from each carcass by Primary PI and NASA BSP. The fecal pellets were extruded from the colon during dissection and were snap frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at -80C.  The fecal pellets were shipped frozen to NASA Ames Research Center and handled by LSDA. Samples were processed and proceeded with a list of assays with details described in the corresponding assay tables including the sample names.     DNA was extracted using the Maxwell RSC Purefood GMO and Authentication Kit (Promega, Madison, WI). Half of a frozen fecal pellet was placed into a tube with 940 uL CTAB solution and homogenized using tissue homogenizing bead mix (Navy RINO Lysis, Next Advance) on Bullet Blender Gold 24 (Next Advance) for 4 minutes at 4C. Homogenates were centrifuged for 3 minutes at 10C and 21,000 g to deflate foam. The supernatant from each sample was then used to isolate and purify DNA following the manufacturer's protocol. DNA was eluted in 105 uL RNAse free H2O and was further cleaned using OneStep PCR Inhibitor Removal Kit (Zymo Research).  Concentrations for all DNA samples were measured using Qubit 3.0 Fluorometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA) with Qubit DNA HS kit. DNA quality and size were assessed using the Agilent 4200 TapeStation with Agilent gDNA ScreenTape Kit (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA).     DNA library was prepared with the Illumina Nextera DNA Flex Library Prep kit (Illumina, San Diego, CA) by GeneLab Sample Processing Lab. Input DNA were approximately ~100 ng. Index adapters were IDT for Illumina, 96-well Nextera Flex Dual Index Adapters, set A. 5 cycles PCR were performed. Library fragment size ~550 bp was assessed using Agilent 4200 TapeStation with D1000 DNA ScreenTape (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA). Multiplexed library concentration was measured with KAPA Library quantification kit (Roche, Wilmington, MA). Library quality control was performed on iSeq100 (Illumina, San Diego, CA).      DNA library prep was performed by the University of Illinois at Chicago. Approximately 300 ng of genomic DNA was sheared by Covaris technology to 350bp fragments. Resulting sheared DNA was bead cleaned with AmpPureXP at a 0.8X bead to DNA ratio. Final DNA concentrations were adjusted to 2ng/ul as measured by the Qubit dsDNA HS assay. 30 ng of sheared DNA was carried through the Swift Accel-NGS 1S Plus DNA kit protocol as described by the company. Resulting libraries were analyzed on the Agilent D1000 TapeStation D1000 and pooled based on nM concentrations. The indexed pool was sequenced on a Mid output MiniSeq run and the observed indexing percentages used to re-pool libraries based on sequencing performance. The normalized sequencing pool was shipped to GeneLab for further sequencing. Normalized pool quality control was performed on iSeq 100 (Illumina, San Diego, CA).     DNA library prep was performed by the University of Illinois at Chicago. 10 ng of genomic DNA was used as input to the Swift 16S + ITS assay. Manufacturers protocol (Cat No. AL-51648) was followed with the only exception being after indexing PCR individual libraries were not processed through the Cleanup step 2. Instead a QC pool was constructed with 2ul of each individual library and then the pool was processed through the cleanup step 2 and library quantitation by qPCR (KAPA). Following quantitation the QC pool was run on Illumina MiniSeq and the resulting % of each index used to construct a new pool with balanced indexing. This re-pool was cleaned up and quantitated as was the QC pool and sent for further sequencing.     DNA library prep was performed by the University of Illinois at Chicago. 10 ng of genomic DNA was used as input to a two-stage PCR amplification protocol (Naqib et al. 2018, Naqib et al. 2019). In the first stage, primers 515F/806R (Earth Microbiome Project) containing Fluidigm 'Common Sequence' linkers (CS1 and CS2) were used to amplify gDNA. In the second stage, Fluidigm AccessArray barcoded primers were used to amplify PCR products from the first stage. This PCR incorporated Illumina sequencing adapters and a sample barcode.  References: 1) Naqib A, Jeon T, Kunstman K, Wang W, Shen Y, Sweeney D, Hyde M, Green SJ. 2019. PCR effects of melting temperature adjustment of individual primers in degenerate primer pools. PeerJ 7:e6570. 2) Naqib, A., Poggi, S., Wang, W., Hyde, M., Kunstman, K. and Green, S.J., 2018. Making and sequencing heavily multiplexed, high-throughput 16S ribosomal RNA gene amplicon libraries using a flexible, two-stage PCR protocol. In Gene expression analysis (pp. 149-169). Humana Press, New York, NY.     Library prep was performed by Loop Genomics. 150 ng genomic DNA was sheared by Covaris g-Tube technology following the manufacturer's recommended setting for 8kb target size. After, sheared DNA was cleaned with SPRIselect bead cleanup at 0.5X ratio and quantified using the Qubit dsDNA HS assay. 10ng of sheared DNA was carried through LoopSeq synthetic long-read library preparation by Loop Genomics (San Jose, CA) using a modified version of the LoopSeq Bacterial Genome kit.  Libraries were analyzed on the Agilent Bioanalyzer High Sensitivity DNA Chip and quantified by KAPA library quantification kit for Illumina.     Whole genome shotgun sequencing was performed by GeneLab Sample Processing Lab on Illumina NovaSeq 6000.  For the libraries prepared with Illumina Nextera DNA Flex Library Prep kit, sequencing was done with paired end 249bp. PhiX included as control.  For the libraries prepared with Swift Accel-NGS 1S Plus DNA kit, sequencing was done with paired end 250bp. 20% PhiX included as control.     The indexed libraries pooled by qPCR quantification were sequenced at Novogene on Illumina HiSeq4000. Paired end 2x150bp reads were used, with a loading concentration of 2nM as determined by qPCR. 10% PhiX included as control. After Illumina sequencing, the raw FASTQ was demultiplexed by Illumina index and then by Loop sample index. Illumina sequencing adaptors were removed using Trimmomatics, and short reads sharing the same molecular barcode were assembled into contigs using SPAdes. The assembled contigs were mapped to a custom-curated database that includes EnsemblBacteria, EnsemblProtists, EnsemblFungi, and human genome.     For the libraries prepared with Swift 16S + ITS assay, sequencing was performed by GeneLab Sample Processing Lab on Illumina iSeq 100. Paired end 149bp. PhiX included as control. For the libraries prepared with Fluidigm Access array, sequencing was performed by the University of Illinois at Chicago on Illumina MiniSeq mid-output flow cell, employing paired-end 2x153 base reads.     Utilizing kraken2 v2.1.1, a human genome reference database was constructed from NCBI's RefSeq (GCF_000001405.39) GRCh38.p13, with --no-masking, and defaults of kmer-length 35 and minimizer-length of 31. FASTQ files were screened against this database, and all successfully classified reads were removed. Fastq-file quality was assessed with FastQC v0.11.9 and results combined with MultiQC v1.11.     Utilizing kraken2 v2.1.1, a mouse genome reference database was constructed from NCBI's RefSeq (GCF_000001635.27) GRCm39, with --no-masking, and defaults of kmer-length 35 and minimizer-length of 31. FASTQ files were screened against this database, and all successfully classified reads were counted and reported as a percentage of the total.     For Nextera and Loopseq assays, quality assessment of reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.11. Quality-trimming and filtering was performed with bbmap v38.86. Read-based processing was performed with humann v3.0.0. Individual samples were assembled with megahit v1.2.9. Genes were called with prodigal v2.6.3. Taxonomic classification of genes and contigs was performed with CAT v5.2.2. Functional annotation was done with KOFamScan v1.3.0. Reads were mapped to assemblies with bowtie2 v2.3.5.1, and coverage information was extracted for reads and contigs with samtools v1.9 and bbmap v38.86. Binning of contigs was performed with metabat2 v2.15. Bins were summarized with bit v1.8.26 and estimates of quality were generated with checkm v1.1.3. High-quality bins (> 90% est. completeness and < 10% est. redundancy) were taxonomically classified with gtdb-tk v1.5.0. For Swift 1S assay, quality assessment of reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.11. Quality-trimming and filtering was performed with bbmap v38.86 (with the swift=t option set). Read-based processing was performed with humann v3.0.0. Individual samples were assembled with megahit v1.2.9. Genes were called with prodigal v2.6.3. Taxonomic classification of genes and contigs was performed with CAT v5.2.2. Functional annotation was done with KOFamScan v1.3.0. Reads were mapped to assemblies with bowtie2 v2.3.5.1, and coverage information was extracted for reads and contigs with samtools v1.9 and bbmap v38.86. Binning of contigs was performed with metabat2 v2.15. Bins were summarized with bit v1.8.26 and estimates of quality were generated with checkm v1.1.3. High-quality bins (> 90% est. completeness and < 10% est. redundancy) were taxonomically classified with gtdb-tk v1.5.0.     Quality assessment of reads was performed with FastQC v0.11.9 and reports were combined with MultiQC v1.9. Primers were removed with cutadapt v2.3. DADA2 v1.20.0 was utilized for quality-trimming and filtering and inference of amplicon sequence variants (ASVs), and taxonomy was assigned with DECIPHER v2.20 using the SILVA r138 reference database.     The absorbed dose of ionizing radiation received by biological payloads on the International Space Station (ISS) depends on a number of factors, including date and duration of exposure and location of the payload on the ISS. Some of the factors that lead to variations in the absorbed dose rate in orbit are ISS altitude, period during the solar cycle, and location of the sample—the ISS module and the specific location within that module.  Shielding effects from the biological payload container or habitat have not been taken into account. The measured absorbed dose can vary based on the dosimetry instrument(s) used. Radiation monitoring on the ISS is not standardized across modules; each international partner has its own suite of instruments, with differing technologies, sensitivities and analysis methodologies, including criteria for distinguishing between lightly ionizing particles (mainly protons) and highly ionizing particles (mainly galactic cosmic ray nuclei). Both active and passive dosimeters are used.  Active dosimeters are powered and data are read out and stored and/or telemetered to ground. Some active dosimeters provide additional levels of detail such as time resolution, energy deposition and particle identification.  Passive dosimeters are unpowered, record constantly and are read out upon return to the ground. The dose in the metadata is the dose recorded by the radiation detector closest to the sample. In most cases that detector will be in the same ISS module; in cases where data from a detector in the same module are not available, the dose is extrapolated using data from periods where data are available from detectors in multiple modules, including the module containing the payload. The duration of the experiment is defined as the time in space during which the specimen was “living”, including the time on the delivery vehicle (e.g. SpaceX Dragon). Once the specimen was frozen or fixed, the experiment was considered stopped.  Details of ISS dosimetry and a table with doses for all GeneLab ISS experiment ISS datasets are available at https://genelab.nasa.gov/environmental/radiation.
_source.Study Description: The objective of the Rodent Research-6 (RR-6) study was to evaluate muscle atrophy in mice during spaceflight and to test the efficacy of a novel therapeutic to mitigate muscle wasting. The experiment involved an implantable subcutaneous nanochannel delivery system (nDS; between scapula), which delivered the drug formoterol (FMT; a selective β2 adrenoceptor agonist), over the course of time. To this end, a cohort of forty 32-weeks-old female C57BL/6NTac mice were either sham operated or implanted with vehicle or treatment-filled nDS, launched in two Transporters (20 mice per Transporter) on SpaceX-13 on December 15, 2017. They were transferred to Rodent Habitats onboard the International Space Station (ISS), and maintained in microgravity for 29 days (N=20, Live Animal Return Spaceflight [LAR FLT]), or >50 days (N=20, ISS Terminal Spaceflight [ISS-T FLT]). After 29 days, the 20 LAR FLT animals were returned live to back to Earth on January 13, 2018. After splashdown, the animals were ambulatory on-ground for ~4 days, until all subjects were processed during one day of dissections. There were two Basal (BSL) groups of animals sacrificed (LAR BSL & ISS-T BSL; N=20; 40 animals; ~36 weeks old) at Kennedy Space Center (KSC; 12/9/17). LAR BSL animals were dissected, and samples were collected upon euthanasia. A Ground Control (GC) group, LAR GC, mimicked the LAR FLT group, which was housed at KSC, then shipped alive, to Novartis’s Facilities, where both the LAR FLT and LAR GC groups were processed (~41 weeks old; 1/16/18). All were anesthetized with isoflurane, blood samples were obtained by closed-chest cardiac puncture, and the animals were euthanized by exsanguination and thoracotomy. The 20 ISS-T FLT mice were anesthetized via intraperitoneal injection of ketamine/xylazine/acepromazine over the course of a four days of dissections (2/6/18 until 2/9/18; 53-56 days after launch; 44 weeks old at time of on-orbit dissections). Blood samples and euthanasia were conducted the same as LAR groups. Following blood draw and hind limb dissection, the ISS-T FLT animal carcasses were wrapped in aluminum foil, placed in a ziploc bag and placed in storage at -80˚C or colder until return. The ISS-T Ground Control (ISS-T GC) (at KSC) followed the same euthanasia timeline, methods, and preservation. The final processing of frozen ISS-T FLT, frozen ISS-T GC and frozen 0-day ISS-T BSL animals were completed at Houston Methodist Research Institute, in Houston, TX (5/21/18 until 5/24/18). GeneLab received feces from only sham treated animals (no drug treated animals) from the following groups. FLT: LAR (n=9), ISS-T (n=7); GC: LAR (N=7), ISS-T (N=9); BSL: LAR (n=7), ISS-T (n=9). DNA was extracted and analyzed by sequencing using a variety of different targeted and un-targeted metagenome profiling assays.
